Lake Aiguebelette spreads its turquoise waters in a preserved mountain setting. Smallest of the great Alpine lakes, it offers the greatest tranquility as motorboats are banned.
The two islands in the lake's center shelter a chapel and the remains of prehistoric lake dwellings classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Lake Bourget stretches 18 kilometers between the mountains. France's largest natural lake, it inspired Lamartine who set his poetic meditations here.
The Royal Abbey of Hautecombe stands on Lake Bourget's western shore. Necropolis of the Princes of Savoy, it houses the dynasty's tombs.
Aix-les-Bains retains its elegance as a Belle Époque spa resort. The national thermal baths and palaces testify to past splendor.
The Temple of Diana and Roman remains recall that thermal waters already attracted spa-goers two thousand years ago.

visits.text: Ambérieu-en-Bugey marks the gateway to Bugey, the transition between Dombes plains and Jura mountains. The town developed around its strategic position at the crossroads of major roads and its railway node. The Saint-Germain church, with its Romanesque bell tower, watches over the old center. The nearby Château des Allymes, perched on a rocky outcrop, testifies to medieval military architecture with its square keep and defensive walls.

The Château des Allymes, built in the 14th century by the Dukes of Savoy, dominates the plain from its 820-meter perch. The fortified ensemble, remarkably preserved, illustrates defensive architecture of the late Middle Ages. The keep, ramparts, and towers allowed control of roads leading to Geneva and Lyon. Guided tours reveal daily life of garrison soldiers. The panoramic view extends from the Alps to Mont Blanc.

Walk through the old town where 19th-century houses bear witness to industrial prosperity brought by the railway. The railway station, built in 1856, marked a decisive turning point in urban development. The adjacent railway museum recounts this epic through period locomotives, tools, and documents. Model trains recreate the network's different eras.

The Albarine gorges, a few kilometers from town, offer spectacular landscapes where the river has carved its bed through limestone rock. Steep cliffs, caves, and natural cavities dot the course of this tumultuous torrent. Marked trails allow safe exploration while admiring geological formations. The site attracts climbers who train on vertical walls.

activities.text: Taste Bugey wines at local producers cultivating terraced hillsides. This little-known appellation produces remarkable white, red, and rosé wines. Altesse, Mondeuse, and Jacquère grape varieties express themselves differently depending on exposure and soil. Independent winegrowers welcome visitors to explain their work and passion. Tastings reveal unexpected diversity of this mountain terroir.

Hike the Sentier des Crêtes which climbs to heights dominating the plain. The marked trail offers spectacular views of the Alps, Mont Blanc, and surrounding valleys. The route alternates between forests, meadows, and rocky passages. The varied flora includes rare orchids and mountain plants. The approximately 4-hour round trip is accessible to regular hikers.

Visit the Tuesday morning market that animates the town center. Stalls overflow with local products: mountain cheeses, Bugey charcuterie, vegetables from market gardens, regional wines. Producers sell directly to customers, perpetuating personal relationship. The friendly atmosphere makes shopping a pleasant moment of exchange.

Practice climbing on the limestone cliffs of Albarine gorges. The site offers routes of all difficulty levels, from beginner to expert. Local clubs organize initiations and supervised outings. The spectacular setting and rock quality attract climbers from the entire region. Equipment rental and professional instruction ensure safety.

visits.text: Amnéville Zoo spreads across 18 hectares with 2,000 animals from 360 species in natural habitats. Gorilla Island houses a family of 12 lowland gorillas, the Tropical Vivarium shelters 500 reptiles, and the polar bear enclosure recreates the Arctic tundra. The African savannah, Asian jungle, and American plains offer immersive scenographies. Educational shows (sea lions, birds of prey) punctuate the 5 km walk, about 4 to 5 hours for a complete visit.

The Amnéville thermal baths draw their 34°C water from a 1,500-meter-deep source rich in trace elements. The 6,000 m² complex features 25 pools (wave pool, whirlpools, aquatic jets), 14 saunas and hammams, and a wellness area. The outdoor lagoon, open year-round, offers winter bathing under snow. Aquagym sessions, underwater massages, and aquabike complement the facilities.

activities.text: Walygator Park, Lorraine's largest amusement park, offers 40 attractions on 45 hectares. The Monster wooden roller coaster reaches 90 km/h, Comet plunges from 35 meters in vertical drop, and Anaconda loops upside down at 80 km/h. Family areas (Octopus, Magic Carousel), water attractions (Colorado River, Gold Mine), and themed shows. May to September, 10 am to 7 pm, full day needed.

The Snowhall indoor ski slope, unique in eastern France, maintains -4°C year-round on its 620-meter main run. Skis, snowboards, sleds, and tubing suit all levels. The 35-meter-high slope includes red and blue runs, a snowpark, and a beginner area. Equipment rental on-site, 2-hour sessions, ski and snowboard lessons available. An alternative for off-season skiing.

Conflans raises its medieval town on a rocky spur overlooking Albertville. This upper town has preserved its ramparts, fortified gates, and arcaded houses.
The Grande Place opens onto a vertiginous panorama embracing the Isère Valley and the snow-capped Alpine peaks. Café terraces invite contemplation.
Cobbled lanes wind between artisan shops and art galleries. Passage under the arcades shelters from showers and sun.
The Red House owes its name to the bricks adorning its medieval facade. This jewel of Savoyard architecture now houses a contemporary art center.
The Baroque church displays its gold and stucco in the shadows. The monumental altarpiece illustrates the religious fervor of the Duchy of Savoy.
Annecy spreads its canals and flower-lined quays at the foot of the Alps. Nicknamed the Venice of the Alps, the old town enchants with cobbled lanes and pastel-colored houses.
The Palais de l'Île rises from the middle of the Thiou like a stone ship. This former 12th-century prison is the most photographed monument in the city.
Cross the Lovers' Bridge linking the Gardens of Europe to the Pâquier. Legend promises eternal love to couples who kiss there.
The Gardens of Europe form a green setting at the lakeside. Century-old plane trees shade the pathways where the statue of chemist Berthollet stands.
Annecy Castle has dominated the old town since the 12th century. Former residence of the Counts of Geneva, it houses a museum dedicated to regional history and Alpine traditions.
Saint-Pierre Cathedral blends Gothic and Renaissance styles. Saint Francis de Sales was ordained Bishop of Geneva here.
The arcades of Rue Sainte-Claire shelter the market on Tuesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. Stalls overflow with cheeses, charcuterie, and local products.
The Visitation Basilica crowns the heights of Annecy. Its soaring bell tower is visible from anywhere in town while interior mosaics illuminate the nave with shimmering colors.
The relics of Saint Francis de Sales and Saint Jeanne de Chantal rest in this basilica built in the early 20th century.
The Semnoz peaks at 1,699 meters offering a 360-degree panorama of Lake Annecy, Mont Blanc, and the Bauges. The winding road crosses forests and alpine pastures.
The Semnoz viewpoint allows a sweeping view of the entire lake, from Talloires to Duingt, with snow-capped peaks as backdrop.
The lake ecomuseum in Sevrier traces the life of fishermen and farmers who lived by the water before the rise of tourism.
Old Town of Annecy – canals, Pont Perrière, Palais de l'Isle (exterior)
Château d'Annecy (esplanades & museums)

Immerse yourself in medieval scholarship at the Scriptorial d'Avranches, a remarkable museum housing the precious manuscript collection from the Mont-Saint-Michel abbey. This exceptional treasury preserves centuries of work by monk copyists, featuring illuminated texts, ornate calligraphy, and priceless documents that reveal the intellectual life of the medieval monastery. Interactive exhibits and meticulous displays unveil the secrets of manuscript creation.

Wander through the magnificent Jardin des Plantes d'Avranches, a member of the prestigious Union of Parks and Gardens of Normandy. This botanical paradise features twelve distinct thematic gardens showcasing diverse plant collections from around the world. The elevated position offers a spectacular panoramic vista across the entire bay to the Mont-Saint-Michel, making it one of the finest viewpoints in the region.

Pay respects at the American Military Cemetery in Montjoie Saint-Martin, a solemn memorial inaugurated in 1956 honoring nearly 4,000 American soldiers who gave their lives during World War II. This beautifully maintained site features rows of white marble crosses and Stars of David set amid immaculate lawns, offering a poignant reminder of the sacrifices made for liberation.

activities.text: Visit the German Military Cemetery at Mont d'Huisnes, France's only German military mausoleum, a distinctive circular structure containing the remains of over 11,000 German soldiers. This unique architectural memorial provides a contemplative space for reflection on the shared human cost of war.

Explore the enchanting Parc du Château de Chantore, a magnificent 19-hectare landscaped estate featuring meandering rivers, cascading waterfalls, and an extraordinary collection of exotic trees. Discover spectacular rhododendrons, camellias, and rare botanical specimens in this romantic parkland that feels like stepping into a living painting.

visits.text: Old center of the former capital of Beaujolais; half-timbered houses and Market Square.
Saint-Nicolas Church and narrow streets climbing towards the hillsides.

Beaujeu, the historic capital that gave its name to the entire Beaujolais region, preserves exceptional medieval heritage. Founded in the 9th century by the Lords of Beaujeu, the town was the seat of a powerful feudal domain controlling the region for four centuries. The vestiges of ramparts, fortified gates, and the seigneurial castle recall this glorious past. The narrow streets and half-timbered houses create an authentic medieval atmosphere.

The Hospices de Beaujeu, founded in 1235, rank among the oldest hospitals in France still in operation. The Gothic facade, chapel with remarkable frescoes, and apothecary with period ceramic jars bear witness to eight centuries of charity. The courtyard garden, maintained according to medieval principles, cultivates medicinal plants once used in care. Guided tours reveal surprising secrets about ancient medicine.

The Temple de Bacchus, housed in a beautiful Renaissance building, serves as the main tasting cellar for Beaujolais wines. The vaulted cellars, dug into rock, maintain ideal temperature and humidity for aging. The sommeliers offer thematic tastings to understand the differences between ten crus and villages Beaujolais. An oenology museum completes the visit with tools and objects related to wine work.

The Sources du Beaujolais visitor center explains the formation of this viticultural region through interactive exhibits. Geological models show how granite and schist give specific characteristics to wines. Videos retrace the history of Beaujolais from Celtic times to today. A terrace offers panoramic views of surrounding vineyards.

activities.text: Hillside loop: wine-growing paths and viewpoints over the Val de Saône (4–5 km).
Marked urban route of remarkable facades.

Visit during the famous Sarmentelles festival in December, marking the official release of Beaujolais Nouveau. The entire town lights up with thousands of vine prunings (sarments) that warm the winter air. Wine flows freely in the streets, producers offer tastings of their latest vintage, and concerts animate every corner. This unique tradition attracts thousands of visitors who share a friendly glass around bonfires.

Explore the Monday market that has taken place on Place de l'Hôtel de Ville for centuries. Stalls overflow with local products: Beaujolais wines of course, but also regional charcuterie, mountain cheeses, and seasonal vegetables. Producers sell directly to consumers, preserving personal relationship and advice. The market atmosphere, both authentic and lively, embodies Beaujolais conviviality.

Hike the Chemins du Beaujolais circuit that starts from the town center. The marked trail climbs to surrounding heights offering spectacular views of vineyard-covered valleys. The route passes through forests, vineyards, and small hamlets where time seems suspended. Information panels explain the landscape's geological and viticultural history.

Take a wine tourism course at the Sources du Beaujolais to deepen your knowledge. Professional sommeliers teach you to identify aromas, understand different crus, and pair wines with dishes. Practical exercises alternate with theoretical explanations in a relaxed and educational atmosphere. Participants leave with tools to better appreciate Beaujolais wines.

visits.text: Bellegarde-sur-Valserine sits at the confluence of the Valserine and Rhône, at the foot of the Jura mountains. The town developed around its strategic position and water power that attracted industries. The Pertes de la Valserine, where the river disappears underground before resurfacing several hundred meters away, constitutes a unique geological phenomenon. The surrounding gorges and caves fascinate with their wild beauty.

The Pertes de la Valserine form a spectacular natural site where the river plunges into a chasm before resurfacing downstream. The water has carved impressive gorges through limestone rock, creating caves, potholes, and underground galleries. Footbridges allow safe observation of this geological phenomenon. The roar of water and wild setting create a striking atmosphere. Educational panels explain the formation of these natural curiosities.

Fort l'Écluse, perched on a rocky outcrop overlooking the Rhône valley, controlled the road to Geneva for centuries. The fortification, built in the 17th century and redesigned by Vauban, illustrates French military architecture evolution. The double fort, upper and lower connected by an underground staircase of 666 steps, impresses with its scale. Guided tours reveal siege secrets and daily life of garrison soldiers.

Walk through the old town where 19th-century houses bear witness to industrial prosperity. The Valserine waterfalls, in the town center, once powered mills and factories. Today they offer a refreshing spectacle and a pleasant walking area. The renovated quays invite strolling along the tumultuous waters.

activities.text: Practice canyoning in the spectacular gorges of the Valserine. Local guides lead groups through natural slides, waterfalls, and natural pools. The activity, suitable for all levels with different difficulty courses, allows spectacular discovery of the landscape. Wetsuits and helmets provided ensure safety and comfort. The refreshing experience and aquatic playground nature delight adventure seekers.

Explore the caves and underground galleries dotting the region. Guided tours reveal impressive stalactites and stalagmites, underground rivers, and mysterious chambers. Constant temperature and humidity create a unique atmosphere. Some caves require crawling through narrow passages, adding adventure to the visit. Professional guides ensure safety while explaining cave formation.

Hike the Crêt de la Neige trail, Jura's highest point at 1720 meters. The marked path climbs through forests before emerging on alpine meadows. The summit offers a breathtaking panorama: Mont Blanc, Geneva Lake, Alps as far as the eye can see. The approximately 5-hour round trip is accessible to regular hikers. Diverse flora includes rare alpine species.

Visit Fort l'Écluse during one of the historical reconstructions organized regularly. Costumed actors recreate scenes from garrison life: military drills, cannon firing, period cooking. Craft demonstrations show soldiers' daily skills. The immersive experience transports visitors into the 18th century. Themed evening tours add a mysterious dimension.

visits.text: Belley was the historic capital of Bugey before giving birth to Brillat-Savarin, father of French gastronomy. Ancient alleyways preserve the charm of an episcopal city.
Saint-Jean-Baptiste Cathedral displays its 19th-century neo-Gothic style. The richly frescoed interior houses an 18th-century Virgin statue miraculously spared by the Revolution.
The 18th-century Episcopal Palace lines up its imposing classical facade on Rue des Cordeliers. French-style gardens extend this architecture of power.
The 16th-century Bailliage Hotel now houses the Tourist Office. Push the door to admire its stone staircases and coffered ceilings.
The Hotel of the Dukes of Savoy displays its octagonal stone tower, witness to Bugey's belonging to the duchy before joining France in 1601.
The Old Gate on Rue Sainte-Marie is not a former town entrance but an elevated passage built to allow monks to reach their garden without crossing the public road.
The Lavours Marsh House Museum presents the flora and fauna of this nature reserve where reconstituted aurochs graze.

activities.text: Follow the heritage circuit from the tourist office to discover mansions with arcades and exterior staircases characteristic of the area.
Taste Tome de Belley, a local raw-milk cheese that pairs wonderfully with Bugey wines.
The Lavours Marsh nature reserve can be explored on foot along boardwalk trails. Reconstituted aurochs graze in the wetland meadows.
Continue to nearby Glandieu Waterfall to admire the department's highest cascade.

visits.text: The Citadel of Bitche, a masterpiece by Vauban and Cormontaigne, dominates the town from its 330-meter-high sandstone peak. Redesigned between 1679 and 1754, it resisted the 230-day siege of 1870 without surrendering, an exceptional feat in the Franco-Prussian War. The audiovisual route 'L'Héroïque Siège' immerses visitors in 500 meters of underground tunnels: casemates, powder magazines, wells, and galleries where soldiers' voices echo. Above, the ramparts offer a 360° panorama of the Northern Vosges.

The Northern Vosges Regional Natural Park stretches over 130,500 hectares of sandstone forests and rock formations. The Park House in Bitche presents the local geology, biodiversity, and Alsatian-Lorraine traditions. Interactive exhibitions on endemic species (lynx, black grouse, peregrine falcon), hiking trails in preserved forests, and discovery of rock castles perched on sandstone peaks. UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve.

activities.text: Hike the Simserhof fortified line, the best-preserved Maginot Line fort. This underground city built between 1930 and 1935 housed 600 soldiers with dormitories, kitchens, infirmary, electric power plant, and ammunition depot. Electric trains circulated in 3 km of galleries connecting 17 combat blocks. The guided tour, enhanced with lighting and sound, recreates the daily life of soldiers. Bring warm clothing, constant 10°C.

Discover the Saint-Louis-lès-Bitche crystal works, founded in 1586 by Lorraine glassmakers. The museum showcases exceptional pieces: 19th-century chandeliers, Art Deco vases, and contemporary creations. Crystal blowing demonstrations by master glassmakers reveal ancestral gestures: harvesting, blowing, cutting, engraving. The company store sells signed pieces. France's oldest crystal works still in operation.

visits.text: The Bourbon castle ruins (13th-15th centuries) crown the town from their rocky spur. These impressive vestiges of the ancestral fortress of the Bourbon dynasty include the Qui-Qu'en-Grogne keep built by Louis II around 1400. Climb the 70 steps to reach the terrace offering panoramic views over Bourbonnais bocage and Tronçais forest.

The classified Belle Époque thermal baths (1886) perpetuate a tradition dating back to Romans. The preserved Neo-Byzantine architecture with polychrome brick facades houses modern facilities treating rheumatism and respiratory conditions. The springs rich in sulfur and minerals have attracted curistes for over 2000 years.

The Saint-Georges church (12th-13th centuries) displays Romanesque architecture with fortified elements. The interior shelters frescoes and carved capitals illustrating medieval art. The massive bell tower dominates old Bourbon testifying to the church's strategic and spiritual role.

Old Bourbon reveals its paved streets lined with stone houses (15th-18th centuries) and half-timbered facades. The town preserves authentic medieval character with ancient ramparts still visible. Stroll discovering artisan shops and café terraces in preserved historical setting.

activities.text: The thermal park extends 15 hectares of landscaped gardens around thermal baths. Marked paths wind through century-old trees, flowerbeds and ponds. The peaceful setting invites relaxation walks away from urban bustle. Benches and pavilions offer rest spots.

The Tronçais Forest surrounds Bourbon offering hiking and biking opportunities. Marked trails explore this exceptional oak forest planted by Colbert in the 17th century. The forest roads lead to remarkable trees, ponds and glades perfect for picnics and nature observation.

visits.text: Discovery of the historic center of Bourg-en-Bresse and its half-timbered houses.
Visit to the Royal Monastery of Brou, a 16th-century flamboyant Gothic masterpiece.
The Royal Monastery of Brou is a jewel of Flamboyant Gothic built in the early 16th century. Margaret of Austria had this complex constructed to house the tomb of her husband Philibert the Fair.
The church displays its glazed roof with multicolored tiles and three cloisters of exceptional delicacy. The sculpted tombs rank among the masterpieces of European funerary statuary.
The 1496 Hugon house illustrates medieval architecture with its stone shop on the ground floor and half-timbered upper floors where the master and his workers lived.
Notre-Dame Co-Cathedral impresses with its 190 years of construction. Its 23-bell carillon rings through the town while its Flamboyant Gothic style rivals Brou.
Stroll through Place de la Grenette dominated by the former neoclassical grain hall and the theater adorned with columns, masks, and music muses.
The 18th-century Town Hall displays a sundial inspired by astronomer Lalande, a local son. Fountains flank the entrance classified as a Historic Monument.
The Fountain of the Four Crossroads, nicknamed Vizirette by locals, symbolizes the world and its four cardinal points in the heart of the pedestrian quarter.

The Royal Monastery of Brou stands like a Bressan Taj Mahal, built out of love between 1506 and 1512. A masterpiece of Flamboyant Gothic architecture, it captivates with its stone lacework, three princely tombs, and poignant history: Margaret of Austria had this mausoleum built for her husband Philibert the Fair, who died too soon. The three cloisters and the Fine Arts Museum complete the visit to this listed monument.

Notre-Dame Church reveals Flamboyant Gothic architecture typical of the Savoy Bresse region. Built with carrons, those characteristic Savoy bricks, it bears witness to the town's medieval past. Its bell tower has watched over the city center for centuries, offering a visible landmark from the surrounding cobblestone streets.

Stroll through the historic center's narrow streets where half-timbered houses tell the story of this former capital of Bresse. Place Carriat and its terraces invite you to observe the daily ballet of the Burgiens. Colorful facades and arcades shelter artisan shops that perpetuate local craftsmanship.

The Ferme du Sougey, a listed historic monument, is one of the oldest half-timbered farms in Bresse, dating from the 15th century. Transformed into a local heritage museum, it showcases traditional Bressan habitat and houses a breeding farm for AOC Bresse poultry. The surrounding 35 hectares of bocage landscape bear witness to ancestral local agriculture.

activities.text: Tasting of the famous Bresse poultry in a local restaurant.
Walk in Tête d'Or park to enjoy the green spaces and the local market.
Pick up the discovery booklet at the tourist office for a self-guided tour of Bourg-en-Bresse's heritage.
The Bouvent leisure center offers 56 hectares of relaxation three kilometers from the center: swimming, paddle boats, climbing, bike park, and golf course.
Sit down to savor PDO Bresse chicken, the only poultry in the world to hold a protected designation of origin.
Continue to the pottery village of Meillonnas in the Revermont to discover faience workshops perpetuating the tradition of the famous blue decorations.

Discover Bresse poultry AOC, the only poultry in the world to benefit from a protected designation of origin since 1957. In local farms and restaurants, taste this fine, marbled meat from chickens raised free-range in the Bressan bocage. Local gastronomy highlights this blue-legged chicken, the region's crown jewel.

Get lost in the cobblestone streets of the Brou district. Old houses, secret passages, and small interior courtyards create a preserved medieval atmosphere. Every facade tells a story, every stone bears witness to the passage of centuries in this city of weavers and merchants.

The market halls buzz every Saturday morning with the activity of local producers. Bresse poultry, mountain cheeses, sausages, thick fresh cream: the stalls overflow with local products. The friendly atmosphere and discussions with producers keep the Bressan agricultural tradition alive.

Visit the apothecary of the former Brou hospital, arranged in the early 18th century. This old pharmacy preserves an exceptional collection of Meillonnas earthenware jars and period medical instruments. Carved woodwork and secret drawers testify to medicine of yesteryear.

Conclude your journey in Cancale, the celebrated oyster capital of Brittany, where the bay's pristine waters have nurtured shellfish cultivation for centuries. This picturesque fishing port charms visitors with its colorful boats, waterfront market stalls, and spectacular views across the bay toward Mont-Saint-Michel. The town's authentic Breton character offers a perfect finale to your exploration of this remarkable coastal region.

activities.text: Customs Officers' Path (GR34) towards Pointe du Grouin (short round trip).

Savor the renowned oysters of Cancale directly at the harborside, where local producers sell their freshly harvested shellfish. The unique mineral-rich waters of the bay impart a distinctive flavor to these prized mollusks, considered among the finest in France. Watch fishing boats return with their catch while enjoying the maritime atmosphere of this working port.

visits.text: Castellane — lively Provençal town, remains of fortifications, posterns and towers.
Notre-Dame du Roc (ext.) — promontory overlooking the Verdon.
Chapel of Notre-Dame-du-Roc.
Old town.

Climb the 262 steps leading to Notre-Dame-du-Roc chapel. The sanctuary stands atop a 184-meter limestone rock dominating Castellane. The panorama embraces village rooftops, the Verdon and the first buttresses of the gorges.

The Verdon gorges display their vertiginous canyon with emerald waters. Cliffs 700 meters high frame Europe's largest canyon. The river has sculpted this geological masterpiece in white Jurassic limestone over millennia.

The Route des Crêtes winds along the edge of the void. Viewpoints follow one another, offering vertiginous plunges into the canyon. Each bend reveals a new perspective on the turquoise meanders of the Verdon and sheer walls.

The old village of Castellane preserves its medieval gates and 14th-century ramparts. Walk through cobbled streets where Provençal houses line up. Place Marcel-Sauvaire brings the town center to life with its market and shaded terraces.

Saint-Victor church blends Romanesque and Baroque architecture. 5th-century baptismal fonts testify to the site's early Christian origins. Restored frescoes illuminate the nave with their vivid colors.

activities.text: Whitewater sports on the Verdon (rafting/canoeing depending on conditions).
Heritage walk in the old town and along the river.
Starting point for the Verdon gorges.

Canyoning plunges you into the heart of Verdon's secondary gorges. Natural slides, jumps into pools and rappels punctuate the descent. Rocky walls enclose crystalline streams in a mineral cathedral atmosphere.

The Martel trail crosses the canyon floor for 16 kilometers. The legendary route follows the traces of 1905 explorers between Chalet de la Maline and Point Sublime. Tunnels carved into rock, metal ladders and aerial passages punctuate this exceptional hike.
Rafting on the Verdon offers thrills in the rapids. Boats glide between canyon walls in a grandiose setting. Calm passages allow admiring cliff fauna and vertiginous cliffs.

visits.text: Notre-Dame Church of Caudebec — Described by Henry IV as "the most beautiful chapel in the kingdom," this 15th-16th century flamboyant Gothic church displays a lace stone facade with 333 statues. Its Renaissance organ and stained glass windows are among the treasures of Norman art.

Maison des Templiers — This 13th-century half-timbered medieval house, one of the oldest in Normandy, houses a local history museum. Its carved beams and low rooms testify to medieval civil architecture.

activities.text: MuséoSeine — This modern museum inaugurated in 2015 retraces the history of the river, navigation and the tidal bore that swept over Caudebec until 1963. Models of Viking ships, barges and river boats evoke 2,000 years of river history.

Caudebec-Villequier Seine Ferry — This free crossing allows you to cross the Seine in a few minutes to reach the north bank. An authentic river experience offering views of the cliffs and meanders of the river.

Boucles de la Seine Normande Regional Nature Park — This 89,000-hectare park protects the Seine meanders, the Brotonne and Roumare forests, marshes and orchards. Hiking, bird watching and discovery of Norman rural heritage.

visits.text: The Cerdon Caves open in the Bugey's limestone cliff. The underground tour reveals stalactites and stalagmites before emerging mid-cliff to a vertiginous panorama.
Explore on foot the network of galleries carved by an underground river. The cool temperature offers welcome refuge during summer days.
The prehistoric park offers workshops introducing ancestral techniques: flint knapping, fire starting, spear-thrower shooting.
The Cerdon Copperworks perpetuates artisanal copper object-making techniques. Craftsmen hammer the metal before visitors' eyes.
The Bonnet Silk Works bear witness to the valley's industrial past. The former factory traces the silk epic in Bugey.
Île Chambod spreads its pebble beaches along the Ain River. The turquoise waters invite swimming amid a setting of cliffs.

Cerdon clings to steep hillsides where vines produce a sparkling rosé wine with the ancestral method. The village developed around viticulture and copper craftsmanship that made its reputation in the 19th century. Narrow streets climb between golden stone houses to the heights dominating the valley. The Cerdon caves, spectacular reculée where a river emerges from rock, offer breathtaking landscapes.

The Cerdon caves form an impressive limestone cirque where the river Cuisance springs from the mountain. The 80-meter-high cliffs shelter numerous cavities explored by speleologists. A marked trail allows discovery of this geological site while remaining safe. Educational panels explain the formation of this reculée and prehistory of occupation. The refreshing setting and spectacular views attract hikers and climbers.

The Cerdon Wine Museum, housed in an old cellar, recounts the history of this unique sparkling wine. Traditional tools, old bottles, and period documents illustrate evolution of production methods. Videos explain the ancestral method giving Cerdon its characteristic pearls. Guided tastings allow appreciation of subtle aromas of this light rosé wine. The museum also recalls the importance of viticulture in local economy.

Walk through the old village where copper craftsmen workshops can still be seen. This ancestral know-how, transmitted for generations, produced renowned pieces: alembics, kettles, decorative objects. Some craftsmen perpetuate the tradition and open their doors for demonstrations. The hammering sound and copper shine fascinate visitors. Shops offer quality artisanal creations.

activities.text: Set off hiking on the vineyard circuit winding through hillsides where Bugey-Cerdon grapes ripen.
Winemakers open their cellars for tastings of the famous sparkling rosé wine, made using an ancestral method without added sugar or yeast.
Paddle down the Ain River by canoe-kayak from Île Chambod. Calm waters suit families while a few rapids add spice to the route.
The Cerdon viewpoint offers a panoramic view of the village nestled in its setting of vineyards and forests.

Taste the Cerdon ancestral method at independent winegrowers who cultivate steep hillsides. Each producer offers their version of this characteristic sparkling rosé, fruit of unique clay-limestone terroir. Small family estates, often 3-5 hectares, perpetuate know-how transmitted for generations. The legendary conviviality of Bugey winegrowers makes each visit a moment of authentic sharing.

Practice speleology in the numerous cavities piercing the limestone massif. Avens, chasms, and underground networks offer all difficulty levels for underground exploration enthusiasts. Local clubs organize beginner outings and expeditions to discover concretions, underground rivers, and majestic galleries. Provided equipment and guidance by certified instructors ensure safety and enjoyment.

Hike the caves and vines circuit crossing hillsides and forests. The marked trail traverses vineyard parcels clinging to steep slopes, climbs to Notre-Dame de Carmier, protective virgin perched on the heights, and descends by Fouge and Malpasset waterfalls. These refreshing waterfalls offer a welcome break during hot summer days.

Discover the industrial history of copper craftsmanship that radiated worldwide in the 19th century. Cerdon exported hotel silverware pieces, alembics, and trays around the world. Some workshops still perpetuate this ancestral know-how of hammered copper work. Demonstrations of repoussé and chasing fascinate with gesture precision and beauty of crafted objects.

visits.text: Chamonix-Mont-Blanc nestles at the foot of Western Europe's roof. This world capital of mountaineering has attracted travelers fascinated by glaciers and granite needles since 1741.
The Aiguille du Midi peaks at 3,842 meters, accessible by the Alps' most vertiginous cable car. The panoramic terrace offers a breathtaking view of Mont Blanc and surrounding peaks.
Step into the Void suspends visitors above 1,000 meters of emptiness in a glass cage. The experience guarantees thrills.
The Panoramic Mont-Blanc gondola links the Aiguille du Midi to Pointe Helbronner in Italy. This aerial journey flies over the Vallée Blanche and its seracs.
Chamonix town center blends traditional chalets with mountaineering shops. The statue of Jacques Balmat points to the summit he first conquered in 1786.
Saint-Michel Church raises its steeple facing the peaks. The neighboring cemetery holds the graves of mountaineers who died in the mountains.
The Montenvers Train has climbed the mountainside since 1908 to the Mer de Glace. This rack railway offers spectacular views of Chamonix's needles.
The Mer de Glace spreads its 7-kilometer glacier, France's longest. The Drus, Grandes Jorasses, and Grépon dominate this river of ice with their vertiginous walls.
The Ice Grotto is visited inside the glacier itself. Carved each summer as the glacier advances 70 meters per year, it reveals ephemeral ice sculptures.
The Glaciorium explains glacier formation and retreat due to climate change. This interpretation center raises awareness about environmental issues.
The Alpine Wildlife Museum presents animals inhabiting the high mountains. Mounted chamois, ibex, and eagles alongside a crystal collection.
430 steps now separate the station from the glacier, eloquent testimony to ice retreat over the decades.

activities.text: Treat yourself to the Aiguille du Midi ascent at day's end to watch the sunset over the Mont Blanc range.
Glaciers can also be discovered on guided hikes with mountain guides who share their passion for the massif.
The QC Terme spa offers hot baths facing the Alpine panorama. Steam from outdoor pools creates a magical atmosphere in winter.
The pedestrian street abounds with mountaineering gear shops and souvenirs. Café terraces offer constant spectacle of the peaks.
The Montenvers station panoramic restaurant offers unbeatable views of the Drus and Grandes Jorasses during lunch.
Experienced hikers can descend on foot to Chamonix via the Montenvers trail through the forest.
In winter, the 20-kilometer Vallée Blanche ski descent is a legendary adventure on the glacier.
The Mont-Blanc Tramway from Saint-Gervais climbs to Nid d'Aigle at 2,372 meters, starting point for climbers.

visits.text: Chanaz nestles along the Savières Canal linking Lake Bourget to the Rhône. This picturesque village is nicknamed the little Venetia of Savoy for its quays lined with flower-bedecked houses.
The navigable canal invites waterside wandering. Pleasure boats pass former salt storehouses converted into artisan workshops.
Steep lanes climb between stone houses with colorful shutters. The village antique shop overflows with treasures collected over decades.
The walnut oil mill still operates the old way. Stone millstones crush the kernels to produce oil with an incomparable taste.
The Romanesque church raises its bell tower above the slate roofs. Interior frescoes date from the 12th century.

activities.text: Rent a canoe-kayak to glide along the Savières Canal to nearby Lake Bourget.
Guided cruises reveal the canal and its wild banks where herons and kingfishers nest.
Push open the doors of artisan workshops housed in former shops: potters, weavers, and wood carvers.
The canalside restaurant serves Savoyard specialties facing the water reflections and colorful facades.

visits.text: Charroux, the only Most Beautiful Village of France in Allier, crowns a hill at 413m altitude. Its cobblestone streets wind between carved stone facades (15th-18th centuries) and half-timbered houses from the 14th century. The Orient and Occident gates mark the location of the old fortifications of this medieval city once a stronghold and commercial crossroads of Bourbonnais.

The 12th-century Saint-Jean-Baptiste church intrigues with its truncated bell tower, a mystery finally solved: lightning beheaded it over the centuries. In the village heart, the Cour des Dames reveals its unique circular architecture, a grassy inner courtyard where facades seem to curve creating a mysterious space. An astonishing place accessible through narrow passages.

The Charroux and Canton Museum occupies 14 rooms spread across two buildings of the old fortification. Collections of objects, documents, sculptures and furniture trace Charroux's history from Gallo-Roman times to the 20th century. A monetary treasure of 600 silver coins from the 12th century testifies to the right to mint currency granted to monks.

Walk through rue de l'Horloge and rue de la Poulaillerie discovering houses with carved stones and hidden courtyards. Maison à la Salamandre, with its François I emblem, and Maison du Prince de Condé with Renaissance decoration illustrate the medieval village's prestige. Panoramic viewpoints over Bourbonnais bocage reveal a patchwork of meadows and hedges.

activities.text: The Charroux mustard house perpetuates artisanal mustard-making since 1988, reviving a tradition dating back to monks. Local mustard seed, white wine from Allier and local honey compose this condiment with subtle flavor. The shop offers tastings and sales of several mustard varieties, sweet to strong.

The Sunday morning market brings life to the village with local producers offering farm products, Charroux mustard, Bourbonnais cheeses and fruits from family orchards. The convivial atmosphere invites tasting and exchanges with artisans perpetuating regional know-how.

The International City of the French Language occupies the former royal château built by Francis I between 1532 and 1540. This Renaissance monument houses a contemporary museum celebrating French language worldwide. Interactive exhibitions explore linguistic evolution, Francophonie and French literary heritage. The restored château reveals sculpted ceilings and period architectural elements.

The Jean de La Fontaine birthplace museum occupies the 16th-century house where the famous fabulist was born in 1621. Period rooms evoke 17th-century daily life. Original editions, manuscripts and illustrations of the Fables present the poet's work. The museum garden recreates a French-style garden from the era.

The Retz Forest unfolds over 13,000 hectares of preserved nature surrounding the town. Ancient oak, beech and chestnut stands create a remarkable woodland landscape. This royal forest where kings once hunted shelters rich fauna and flora.

The medieval castle ruins crown the hilltop dominating the Marne valley. Remains of fortifications, towers and curtain walls testify to this feudal fortress's strategic importance. Panoramic viewpoints over town and valley reward the climb. Interpretation panels recount castle and region history.

Alexandre Dumas Museum pays tribute to the famous writer born in Villers-Cotterêts in 1802. The birth house presents manuscripts, editions and objects belonging to the Three Musketeers and Count of Monte-Cristo author. Temporary exhibitions explore various aspects of his prolific work.
Old Château Gate is the only remaining vestige of medieval enclosure. This fortified gate defended town access. Massive stonework and defensive elements illustrate medieval military architecture.
Walk through the historic center discovering old houses and remarkable facades. The town preserves architectural heritage testifying to its royal past. Saint-Nicolas Church dominates the main square.
Walk along the Marne River banks offering pleasant waterside strolls. The quays invite strolls between town and nature. Pleasure boats and fishing spots enliven this fluvial landscape.

activities.text: Hike marked Retz Forest trails offering loops from 5 to 20 kilometers. Paths wind through century-old stands to remarkable trees including giant oaks. The peaceful forest invites walking and nature observation.
The Château-Thierry slopes produce Champagne under the appellation. Several houses offer cellar visits and tastings. The Champagne Route winds between vineyards and wine villages of the Marne valley.

Discover local products at the Wednesday and Saturday morning market. Producers offer cheeses, cured meats, vegetables and regional specialties. The convivial atmosphere invites strolling and tasting.
Stroll through downtown streets dotted with private mansions from the 17th and 18th centuries. La Fontaine's statue stands on the renovated square. Facades tell the history of this literary city.

Visit craft workshops perpetuating traditional skills. Local artisans work wood, leather and textiles according to ancestral methods. Demonstrations reveal technical gestures transmitted through generations.
The Jean de La Fontaine Festival brings the town to life each year in May. Music, theater and dance celebrate Château-Thierry's cultural heritage during this artistic event.
Cycle the paths linking Villers-Cotterêts to surrounding villages through forest and countryside. Several circuits cross the Retz massif offering varied landscapes and heritage discovery.

visits.text: Châtillon-sur-Chalaronne displays its red bricks and half-timbering in the heart of the Dombes. France's first bee-friendly town, it proudly wears its four flowers and labels as a blooming city.
The 15th-century Market Hall hosts every Saturday morning the local produce market voted Most Beautiful Market in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region. Stalls overflow with Bresse terroir products.
The apothecary of the former hospital preserves a unique collection of 120 Meillonnas faience jars with blue and white decorations. 18th-century woodwork frames this pharmaceutical treasure.
Pass through the Villars Gate, vestige of the fortified town, to reach the ramparts of the old castle that have dominated the town since the 12th century.
Flower-decked bridges span the Chalaronne as it winds between half-timbered houses. The 14th-century salt storehouse testifies to the town's commercial importance in the Middle Ages.
The Saint Vincent de Paul House recalls that it was here the saint conceived the idea of creating the Ladies of Charity. An exhibition traces his humanitarian work.
Discover the history of botanist Philibert Commerson, a local son who accompanied Bougainville and discovered, among other things, the hydrangea.

Châtillon-sur-Chalaronne charms with its flowered canals and Burgundian-style half-timbered houses reflected in the clear waters of the Chalaronne. The medieval town, former border of the Duchy of Savoy, has preserved its defensive character with fortified gates and watchtowers. The eleven bridges that span the river create a romantic landscape worthy of the most beautiful Venetian canals.

The covered market, built on wooden pillars in 1440, stands as one of the finest examples of Bresse civil architecture. Under its impressive oak framework, merchants have set up stalls for six centuries. Local producers still offer Bresse specialties there every Saturday: poultry, cheeses, vegetables from the market gardens.

The former Hôtel-Dieu hospital, founded in 1442, houses a remarkable apothecary with 120 ceramic jars from Meillonnas. The painted woodwork, period medical instruments, and herb drying room plunge visitors into 18th-century medicine. The nuns' chapel and patients' rooms complete this fascinating journey through time.

Follow the Heritage Trail that winds through narrow streets and along canals. Informative panels reveal the history of brick houses, stone bridges, and wash houses where Bressan women came to do their laundry. The Saint-André gate and the Clock Tower punctuate this walk through medieval history.

activities.text: The municipal Arboretum gathers 342 exceptional tree varieties. The educational apiary welcomes thousands of children each year to explain the essential role of bees.
Push open the doors of art workshops where stained glass makers, bookbinders, and ceramicists perpetuate traditional crafts. The town is labeled a City of Arts and Crafts.
Sit down at one of the restaurants to savor fresh frogs' legs, PDO Bresse chicken, and carp from the Dombes ponds.

Rent a canoe to explore the Chalaronne from the water and discover hidden perspectives of the town. The calm current makes navigation accessible to everyone, even beginners. Passing under arched bridges and along flowered gardens offers a bucolic experience. Swans and ducks accompany paddlers along this aquatic walk.

Stroll through the exceptional flower gardens that earned Châtillon the title of 4-flower town. Terraced gardens descend to the water, geraniums cascade from windows, and roses climb ancient facades. The municipal park and its century-old trees invite contemplation and rest.

Visit the Dream Train Museum, unique in Europe, which brings together an exceptional collection of old toy trains. Miniature landscapes recreate various French and European regions. Animated dioramas fascinate young and old with their precision and realism. Rare pieces and collector trains complete this nostalgic journey.

Attend the Saturday morning market that transforms the town center into a vibrant agora. Stalls overflow with local products: Bresse chickens, Dombes fish, seasonal vegetables, mountain cheeses. The festive atmosphere and exchanges with producers perpetuate an ancestral market tradition.

visits.text: The Saint-Martin Church mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles. The bell tower stands watch over the town with its 15th-century chime. Stained glass windows from various periods illuminate the nave.
Wander along the Oise and canal banks. The river meanders through the town offering walks along the water. Locks and boats punctuate this fluvial landscape.
The covered market built in Art Deco style shelters merchant stalls. The metal structure and geometric decorations reflect post-war reconstruction.
The Chauny countryside unfolds between fields and canals. Villages preserve rural heritage with old farms and churches. Country roads invite exploration of this preserved agricultural territory.

activities.text: Cycle along the Oise greenway following the river's meanders. The converted towpath offers a flat route suitable for all levels. Locks, villages and nature follow one another along this bucolic route.
Fish for pike, zander and bream in the Oise and canals. Anglers find well-equipped spots along the banks. Fishing permit required.
Explore the surrounding forests offering marked hiking trails. Paths wind through beech and oak groves in preserved massifs. Several loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks.

visits.text: Chiroubles, the highest cru of Beaujolais perched at 400 meters altitude, produces elegant and delicate wines nicknamed the 'flowers of Beaujolais.' The village clings to granite hillsides overlooking valleys dotted with vineyards and forests. This elevated position creates a unique microclimate that gives wines their distinctive finesse and floral character.

The Terrasse de Chiroubles offers a breathtaking 360-degree panorama over the entire Beaujolais region. On clear days, the view extends to Mont Blanc and the Alps in the east, the Monts du Forez in the west. Information panels identify the different Beaujolais crus visible from this exceptional belvedere.

The Church of Saint-Étienne, with its Romanesque bell tower, watches over the village from its elevated position. The interior houses a remarkable collection of religious furniture and ex-votos testifying to popular devotion. The stained glass windows filtered by the sun create a mystical atmosphere conducive to meditation.

The Victor Pulliat Museum, housed in a former wine storehouse, pays tribute to this ampelographer who revolutionized viticulture in the 19th century. Pulliat studied grafting to save French vines from phylloxera. Tools, documents, and explanatory panels retrace his essential work for world viticulture.

activities.text: Discover Chiroubles wines through tastings at independent winegrowers who cultivate steep hillsides. This lightest and most aromatic cru of Beaujolais reveals notes of violet, peony, and red fruits. Producers explain the influence of altitude on ripeness and the delicate balance they seek. Small family estates, often spanning 5-10 hectares, welcome visitors with legendary Beaujolais conviviality.

Hike the Sentier des Crus trail that crosses vineyards while offering spectacular views of the Alps. The 8 km marked loop passes through different climats and explains the geological particularities of granite terroir. Resting areas allow you to contemplate the landscape while enjoying a snack. The gentle slopes make this walk accessible to families.

Visit during the Fête des Crus in April, when the entire village celebrates the new vintage. Producers open their cellars for free tastings, street entertainment animates the streets, and regional specialties are served on every corner. The festive and authentic atmosphere showcases Beaujolais conviviality.

Take a mountain bike ride on trails winding through vineyards and forests. Local circuits offer all difficulty levels, from beginner to expert. The varied terrain alternates between forest paths and vineyard roads. Bike rental shops in the village provide quality equipment and detailed maps.

visits.text: Coucy Castle raises its spectacular ruins on a wooded spur. Built in the 13th century by Enguerrand III, this medieval fortress dominated the region with its 54-meter keep before German troops dynamited it in 1917. The massive ramparts and imposing towers still testify to the grandeur of this feudal palace. The site offers one of the finest examples of medieval military architecture.

The medieval town surrounds the castle with its ramparts and fortified gates. The Porte de Laon and Soissons Gate open the enclosure protecting the upper town. Cobblestone streets lead to Saint-Sauveur church and half-timbered houses.
The underground cellars dug beneath the castle served as storage and refuge. Vaulted galleries carved into rock reveal medieval construction techniques. These spaces now host cultural events.
The Saint-Aubin Park surrounds the castle over several hectares. Wooded paths wind through greenery offering viewpoints over ruins and surrounding countryside. Picnic areas invite outdoor breaks.

activities.text: The castle historical show brings the medieval era to life with jousts, falconry and knight combats. This spectacle recreates 13th-century atmosphere with period costumes and authentic weapons. Performances occur during summer and certain weekends.
Walk the marked forest trails surrounding Coucy. Several loops cross the massif through beech and oak groves. Paths lead to panoramic viewpoints over the valley.
Visit the museum evoking castle and town history. Collections include medieval objects, weapons, period models and documents. Interactive displays explain fortress construction and strategic role.

visits.text: Dieppe Castle — This 15th-century fortress perched on a cliff houses a museum exhibiting one of France's finest collections of carved ivories. Dieppe was Europe's main ivory working center in the 17th and 18th centuries.

Saint-Jacques Church — This 13th-16th century church mixes Gothic and Renaissance styles. Its sculpted frieze representing a procession of Brazilian Indians commemorates the 1520 expedition that brought exotic wood from Brazil to Dieppe.

Puits Salé Square — This central square lined with cafes hosts Saturday morning's famous fish market where fishermen sell their catch directly. An authentic and lively place appreciated by Dieppe residents and visitors.

activities.text: Dieppe Beach — This kilometer-long pebble beach is France's oldest seaside resort. The 1930s seafront promenade, Belle Époque villas and beach cabins bear witness to 400 years of bathing history. Kite flying is a local tradition.

Pollet District — This former fishermen's district clinging to the cliff preserves narrow cobbled alleys and sailors' houses. The stairs climbing to the castle offer changing perspectives on the port and the English Channel.

August 19, 1942 Memorial — This museum commemorates the Dieppe Raid when 6,000 Allied soldiers, mainly Canadians, attempted a landing. Photographs, testimonies and objects evoke this tragic episode that cost 3,600 lives.

days_plan.itin_title: Haute-Savoie Alpine Road Trip: Lakes, Mountain Villages & Iconic Peaks

visits.text: The Geological Reserve of Haute-Provence reveals its fossil treasures. Marine imprints emerge from limestone rock, witnesses of a vanished ocean 300 million years ago. The geological trail leads you through ammonite slabs and fossilized ichthyosaurs.

The Gassendi Museum combines contemporary art and natural sciences in an unexpected dialogue. Naturalist collections sit alongside installations by resident artists. Zenith light floods the main gallery where Andy Goldsworthy's works and geological specimens interact.

Discover the limestone rock that rises above Digne-les-Bains like a stone ship. Steep trails lead to the summit where views embrace the spa town and surrounding valleys. The perched chapel has watched over the city since the Middle Ages.

The Digne Thermes have been exploiting sulfurous waters gushing at 42°C since 1930. The spa offers treatments and balneotherapy in a preserved Art Deco setting. The thermal gardens provide a relaxing haven in the shade of century-old plane trees.

The old town displays its ochre facades and shaded squares. Stroll through medieval alleys where fountains murmur their freshness. Boulevard Gassendi brings the city center to life with its Provençal craft shops and welcoming terraces.

activities.text: The Train des Pignes winds from Digne to Nice through the pre-Alps. The historic route uses vertiginous tunnels and viaducts. Landscapes shift from olive trees to fir trees, offering a unique railway spectacle in Provence.
Digne-les-Bains is the ideal starting point to explore the Verdon gorges. Scenic roads lead toward Castellane and the canyon entrances. Plan a full day for this memorable excursion.
Hiking trails crisscross the surrounding hills. Mont Saint-Pancrace offers a moderate ascent rewarded by a 360-degree panorama. Oaks and Aleppo pines punctuate the routes with their welcome shade.

Aval Cliff — This 80-meter-high chalk cliff carved by erosion forms a natural arch nicknamed "Elephant" for the shape of its pillar dipping into the sea. The Needle rising 70 meters inspired Arsène Lupin's hidden treasure in Maurice Leblanc's adventure novel.

Amont Cliff — This arch east of the beach is topped by the Notre-Dame-de-la-Garde chapel and a monument to aviators Nungesser and Coli who disappeared in 1927 attempting the first transatlantic crossing. The path offers dizzying views of the Manneporte.

Manneporte — This third monumental arch 30 meters high pierces the cliff west of the Aval. Accessible only at low tide via the beach, it reveals caves carved by the sea. Monet painted it several times between 1883 and 1886.

Étretat Gardens — These contemporary gardens perched on the cliff combine contemporary sculptures and plants from five continents. The walking path leads to a belvedere offering a 180° panorama from Le Havre to Fécamp.

Yport — This authentic fishing village nestled in a cliff valley preserves its traditional character with its thatched-roof fishermen's huts called "calets." The beach offers a view of Étretat's arches 4 kilometers away.

Fécamp Abbey Church — This 12th-century Benedictine abbey houses a relic of the Holy Blood brought back from the Crusades. Its 127-meter length makes it one of the longest churches in France. The Lady Chapel preserves Renaissance sculptures.

Bénédictine Palace — This neo-Gothic palace built in 1888 houses the distillery of the famous liqueur created by a Fécamp monk in 1510. The museum displays a collection of liturgical art and the recipe room reveals some of the 27 plants used.

activities.text: Coastal hike — GR® towards Aval gate (portion)

Étretat Beach — This pebble beach framed by cliffs attracted Parisian high society in the 19th century. Beach cabins and Belle Époque villas lining the seafront perpetuate this bathing heritage. Swimming depends on tides and currents.

Clos Arsène Lupin — This villa where Maurice Leblanc lived from 1918 to 1939 has been transformed into a museum dedicated to the gentleman burglar. Period rooms, secret passages and scenographic installations bring the adventures to life.

GR21 Hiking Trail — This coastal path connecting Le Havre to Le Tréport runs along the cliff tops. The Étretat section offers spectacular views of the arches and the English Channel. Count 3 hours to reach Yport.

Cap Fagnet — This cliff rising 110 meters north of Fécamp offers a panorama of the Alabaster Coast. The sailors' chapel and the orientation table help identify Étretat, Saint-Valéry and the Normandy Bridge on clear days.

Fisheries Museum — Housed in a former cod-drying plant, this museum retraces Fécamp's great era when 80 trawlers sailed to Newfoundland banks. Models, tools and testimonies evoke the harsh life of cod fishermen.

Port of Fécamp — This fishing port, France's 4th largest, welcomes trawlers daily. The fish market in the early morning and the restaurants of the quays offer the day's catch: scallops, sole, turbot according to the season.

Évian-les-Bains displays its spa resort elegance on Lake Geneva's shores. Mineral waters have sprung from the sources for centuries, attracting spa-goers and celebrities from around the world.
The Palais Lumière, former thermal baths converted to an exhibition center, sports its Belle Époque facade adorned with ceramics and Art Nouveau ironwork.
The Cachat spring flows freely in a kiosk where anyone can fill their bottle with this world-famous water.
The historic funicular has climbed Évian's heights since 1907. This rack railway links the lower town to residential neighborhoods overlooking the lake.
The Lumière Villa, former property of the cinema-inventing brothers, now houses the town hall. The gardens offer panoramic views of Lake Geneva.
Thonon-les-Bains lines up its viewpoints above the lake. The Chablais Museum at Sonnaz Castle dominates this exceptional panorama.
Ripaille Castle spreads its medieval towers in a 53-hectare park. Amédée VIII, first Duke of Savoy, retired here before becoming Pope Felix V.

activities.text: Walk along the banks of the Rhône.
The Évian market enlivens the quays on Tuesday and Friday mornings. Local producers sell cheeses, charcuterie, and Chablais vegetables.
The thermal baths offer wellness cures and relaxing treatments in heated pools facing the lake.
The Saint-François de Sales Basilica in Thonon houses monumental frescoes by painter Maurice Denis. Vibrant colors illuminate the neo-Byzantine interior.
Taste Ripaille wines produced in the castle vineyard, one of the northernmost in France.

visits.text: Fère-en-Tardenois Castle raises its Renaissance ruins on a wooded height. The 16th-century vestiges testify to refined architecture commissioned by princes. Towers and curtain walls emerge from vegetation in a romantic atmosphere.

The fortified Saint-Macre church displays its defensive keep and loopholes characteristic of Thiérache. Though located further south, it shares the religious military architecture of the border region.
The nearby Templar Chapel recalls the military order's presence in the region. This small medieval building merits a visit for its history.
The picturesque village preserves rural charm with its old houses and quiet streets. The verdant setting invites leisurely strolls.

activities.text: Fère Forest unfolds its hiking trails around the village. Forest paths follow streams and clearings in a preserved massif. Several marked loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks.
Surrounding ponds welcome anglers in peaceful settings. Predator fish and coarse fish populate these developed waters. Fishing permit required.
Country roads link Tardenois villages through rolling landscapes and grain fields. Rural heritage reveals itself at the slow pace of cycling.

visits.text: Fleurie, the 'Queen of Beaujolais,' produces arguably the most elegant and refined wines of the region. The 880 hectares of vines unfold on pink granite hillsides that give the wine its characteristic finesse. The village itself charms with its golden stone houses and Romanesque chapel overlooking the vineyards. Fleurie embodies the perfect balance between viticultural excellence and preserved architectural heritage.

The Madonna Chapel, perched on the hill overlooking Fleurie, offers a breathtaking panorama of the vineyards stretching to the horizon. Built in the 19th century, it became a place of pilgrimage for winegrowers seeking protection for their harvests. The stained glass windows depict wine-related scenes, celebrating the sacred bond between faith and viticulture. The walk to reach it crosses the most beautiful parcels of the appellation.

The village center preserves remarkable wine architecture with vaulted cellars, sculpted doorways, and period wineries. Golden stone facades reflect warm light at dusk, creating a romantic atmosphere. The central square and its century-old plane trees provide a shaded meeting place where producers and visitors exchange impressions on the latest vintage.

The Caveau des Producteurs du Cru Fleurie groups together sixty independent winegrowers under one roof. This cooperative tasting room allows discovery of wine diversity despite the common appellation. Each parcel, each climat brings subtle nuances that passionate producers decipher. Modern architecture contrasts with ancient cellars while respecting the site.

activities.text: Taste Fleurie wines at renowned estates like Clos de la Roilette or Domaine de la Grand'Cour. These elegant wines, with silky tannins and aromas of iris and violet, represent the quintessence of Beaujolais. Producers explain the influence of pink granite on finesse and the winemaking techniques that preserve aromatic delicacy. Some estates offer vertical tastings of several vintages to understand evolution over years.

Walk the Wine Trail that crosses the most beautiful climats of the appellation: La Roilette, Grille-Midi, Les Moriers. Information panels explain the influence of exposure, slope, and soil composition on wine character. The 5 km loop offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days and passes through century-old vines.

Attend a wine and cheese pairing workshop organized by local sommeliers. Young Beaujolais cheeses, goat cheeses from nearby mountains, and aged Comté accompany different cuvées of Fleurie. Professionals explain harmony principles between wine tannins and cheese textures. The convivial format encourages exchanges between participants.

Cycle through vineyards on the Beaujolais Wine Route. The gentle slopes make cycling accessible while offering exceptional panoramas. The route connects Fleurie to neighboring villages, passing through varied landscapes of vineyards, forests, and small valleys. Electric bike rental makes climbs effortless.

visits.text: The citadel crowns the hill above Forcalquier. Medieval ruins dominate the town and plain with their austere walls. Notre-Dame-de-Provence chapel watches from the summit, offering a circular panorama over the Alps, Luberon and Montagne de Lure.

The Cordeliers convent displays its 13th-century Franciscan monastic architecture. The Gothic cloister with vaulted galleries surrounds a simple garden. Temporary exhibitions and concerts regularly animate this carefully restored historic place.

Notre-Dame-du-Bourguet cathedral blends Romanesque and Provençal Gothic. The 13th-century sculpted portal opens onto a harmoniously proportioned nave. Side chapels house richly decorated Baroque altarpieces.

Walk through old town streets where mansions and Renaissance residences line up. Medieval gates punctuate the former ramparts' layout. Restored fountains and washhouses mark shaded squares where Provençal gentleness reigns.
Saint-Michel cemetery offers a peaceful haven away from town. Terraced tombs follow the hillside slope. Cypresses stand like sentinels in this serene place.

activities.text: Forcalquier market brings the town to life every Monday morning. Considered one of Provence's most beautiful markets, it spreads its colorful stalls across several squares. Local producers, artisans and market gardeners offer goat cheeses, lavender honey, olives and local specialties.

Montagne de Lure rises north of Forcalquier. Forest roads wind through beech groves and alpine meadows to the 1826-meter summit. The astronomical observatory benefits from clear skies for its observations.
Hiking trails radiate around Forcalquier. The Montagne des Mourres tour offers a moderate route through garrigue and oaks. Medieval ruins and Alpine panoramas punctuate the itineraries.

visits.text: Discover the Ecomusée de la Baie, an enlightening interpretation center dedicated to the natural wonders of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay and its protected ecosystems. Spread across 400 square meters, this engaging museum features films, detailed scale models, and interactive terminals that explain the unique environment of Europe's greatest tidal bay. The museum offers unobstructed views toward the iconic silhouette of the mount.

Explore the charming coastal village of Genêts, a quintessentially Norman settlement that serves as the traditional starting point for guided bay crossings. This picturesque harbor community retains its authentic maritime character with stone cottages, fishing boats, and a peaceful atmosphere that contrasts beautifully with the drama of the surrounding tidal flats.

activities.text: Embark on the legendary barefoot crossing of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay, an unforgettable adventure through one of the world's most dramatic tidal landscapes. Accompanied by an expert guide, wade through shallow channels, discover the phenomenon of quicksand safely, and experience the vast scale of this UNESCO-listed natural site. The bay witnesses Europe's highest tidal variations, creating an ever-changing seascape of extraordinary beauty.

Observe the remarkable wildlife that thrives in the bay's unique ecosystem, including elegant egrets, graceful seals, and the famous pré-salé sheep that graze the salt marshes. The herbus-coastal meadows regularly covered by tides-support an extraordinary biodiversity and create the distinctive flavored lamb that is a regional culinary treasure.

Begin your journey in Granville, a captivating fortified town perched dramatically on a rocky promontory that marks the northern boundary of the Mont-Saint-Michel bay. This historic corsair city enchants visitors with its impressive ramparts encircling a charming old town of granite houses and narrow cobblestone streets. Stroll along the defensive walls for breathtaking panoramic views over the English Channel and the distant silhouette of the Chausey archipelago.

Discover the beautiful sandy beaches of Granville that stretch beneath the imposing cliffs of the upper town. These pristine shores offer a perfect blend of seaside relaxation and dramatic coastal scenery, with the tides revealing fascinating rock formations and tide pools teeming with marine life.

Embark on an unforgettable boat excursion to the Chausey Islands, a stunning archipelago featuring 365 islets at low tide and 52 at high tide. This maritime adventure reveals one of Europe's most remarkable tidal environments, where crystal-clear waters, white sand beaches, and abundant wildlife create a pristine natural sanctuary just offshore from the mainland.

visits.text: Hauteville-Lompnes unfolds on a plateau at 800 meters altitude, benefiting from an exceptional climate that earned it the nickname 'Little Switzerland.' The town developed in the 19th century thanks to tuberculosis sanatoria that attracted thousands of patients. Period architecture, large parks, and tree-lined avenues testify to this past. Today, medical institutions have been converted while preserving their heritage character.

The Church of Saint-Pierre, rebuilt in the 19th century, stands out with its imposing neo-Gothic facade. The interior houses remarkable stained glass windows and period religious furniture. The bell tower serves as a landmark visible from the entire plateau. The peaceful square invites contemplation while enjoying pure mountain air.

Walk through the Vallon park, a green oasis in the heart of town. Century-old trees, flowerbeds, and winding paths create a romantic atmosphere inherited from the sanatorium era. The arboretum presents rare species adapted to mountain climate. Children's play areas and picnic tables attract families. The park hosts outdoor concerts in summer.

The Plateau de Retord, accessible by small mountain roads, offers spectacular wild landscapes. Vast expanses of meadows alternate with dense forests. The plateau, at 1200 meters altitude, serves as a Nordic skiing area in winter. In summer, hikers discover intact nature and exceptional panoramas extending to Mont Blanc. Marmots and chamois can be observed with binoculars.

activities.text: Cross-country ski on the Plateau de Retord, one of the finest Nordic domains in the region. Fifty kilometers of groomed trails wind through forests and clearings. All difficulty levels are represented, from gentle beginner loops to demanding courses for experts. Equipment rental and ski lessons are offered on site. The snowy landscapes and pure air create a magical atmosphere.

Hike the marked trails crossing Bugey mountains. The Crêt du Nu trail climbs to a belvedere offering 360-degree views of the Alps and Jura. The route passes through spruce forests, mountain pastures, and rocky passages. Diverse flora includes gentians, edelweiss, and rare orchids. The approximately 3-hour round trip is accessible to regular hikers.

Discover local gastronomy featuring mountain products. Restaurants serve comté cheese, smoked meats, blueberry tart, and Bugey wines. Some establishments perpetuate recipes from the sanatorium era when refined cuisine aided patient recovery. The warm atmosphere and hearty portions embody mountain conviviality.

Visit the Wednesday morning market that brings together local producers. Mountain cheese makers, vegetable gardeners, beekeepers offer quality products. Direct sales and advice from producers make shopping a moment of authentic exchange. Regional specialties - honey, jams, liqueurs - reflect mountain terroir wealth.

visits.text: Hérisson, medieval city labeled Petite Cité de Caractère, sits perched above Aumance gorges. The picturesque site reveals rampart remains, fortified gates and old houses (15th-17th centuries). The Porte de Varenne and Porte de la Bade mark former medieval enclosure entrances. Views over valley and surrounding forests are spectacular.

The fortress ruins dominate the village from their rocky promontory. Towers, curtain walls and keep vestiges testify to this strategic stronghold's medieval power. The Bourbon coat of arms carved in stone recalls lords who controlled this border territory. Climb the ramparts for panoramic views over Combrailles.

The Saint-Pierre church (12th-15th centuries) mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles. The carved portal and interior capitals display medieval stonemason art. Stained glass windows from various periods illuminate the modest nave testifying to village religious life through the ages.

Walk along Aumance discovering old wash houses and mills lining the river. The green banks invite peaceful strolls in nature. Footbridges and footpaths allow exploring gorges where water carved a picturesque path through rock.

activities.text: Hiking trails depart from Hérisson village exploring surrounding forests and valleys. Marked paths wind through woods, meadows and along Aumance. Several loops allow 2 to 4 hour walks discovering preserved natural and built heritage.

The artisan market in summer brings village to life with regional product stalls. Local producers offer cheeses, cured meats, jams and crafts. The friendly atmosphere invites tasting and conversation with artisans.
