days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Lyon Region Road Trip: Vineyards, Mountains & Golden Stone Villages

visits.text: Juliénas, the northernmost cru of Beaujolais, unfolds its vineyards on granite hillsides that give character to its powerful and structured wines. Legend attributes the village's name to Julius Caesar, who supposedly planted the first vines here. The Château du Bois de la Salle, a former commandery, dominates the appellation and houses a renowned tasting cellar.

The Church of Saint-Just-et-Saint-Pasteur stands atop the hill, offering a panoramic view of the vineyards stretching to the horizon. Its Romanesque bell tower watches over the vines that have made the village's reputation for centuries. The stained glass windows depict wine-related scenes, celebrating the inseparable bond between faith and viticulture.

The former church of Juliénas, now a wine cooperative, represents a unique architectural conversion. The sacred building, deconsecrated in the 1950s, was transformed into a cathedral dedicated to wine. Frescoes by artists Victor Charreton and Paul Borel adorn the walls, celebrating wine and work in the vineyards.

Walk through the old village where golden stone houses bear witness to the prosperity brought by wine. The vaulted cellars, dug directly into granite, maintain constant temperature ideal for wine aging. Some cellars open their doors to reveal bottles dating back several decades.

activities.text: Taste Juliénas wines in one of the many estate cellars. This cru, produced on only 600 hectares, reveals rich aromas of red fruits and spices. Independent winegrowers passionately explain the influence of granite terroir on character. The convivial tasting includes several vintages to understand the evolution over the years.

Hike the Cru Trail that winds through vineyards and offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days. The marked path passes through the different climats that make up the appellation: Juliénas, Les Mouilles, Les Capitans. Information panels explain viticultural practices and the influence of terroir.

Visit the Cellier de la Vieille Église, a former cooperative transformed into a tasting temple. The frescoes depicting vineyard work and winemaking techniques create a unique atmosphere. Tastings are accompanied by explanations of specific characteristics of Juliénas wines compared to other Beaujolais crus.

Participate in a traditional cooking workshop pairing Juliénas wines with Beaujolais terroir dishes. Local chefs teach how to prepare coq au vin, beef à la Juliénas, and Beaujolais tart. Each dish is carefully paired with an appropriate vintage to enhance flavors.

days_plan.itin_title: Ain Road Trip: Bresse Plains and Bugey Mountains

visits.text: Jumièges Abbey — Victor Hugo called these ruins "the most beautiful in France." Founded in 654, this Benedictine abbey preserves its twin Romanesque towers 46 meters high dating from 1067. The roofless nave open to the sky and the cloister evoke the grandeur of medieval monasticism.

Saint-Pierre Church of Jumièges — This 10th-century Carolingian church next to the abbey displays pre-Romanesque architecture with its irregular pillars and rough stone walls. One of the rare testimonies to Norman architecture before the year 1000.

Seine Viewpoint from Jumièges — The abbey's elevated position offers panoramic views of the Seine loop and surrounding forests. The sunset illuminating the ruins creates a romantic atmosphere that inspired 19th-century writers.

Saint-Martin-de-Boscherville Abbey — This 12th-century Romanesque abbey, remarkably preserved, displays a purity of lines characteristic of Norman architecture. Its chapter house and 17th-century French-style gardens with their yew topiaries create a meditative setting.

Ruins of Château Robert le Diable — This fortress perched on a rocky outcrop overlooking the Seine dates from the 12th century. Legend attributes its construction to Robert the Magnificent, father of William the Conqueror. The panorama spans the valley.

activities.text: Abbey Gardens — These 15-hectare landscaped gardens surrounding the ruins include century-old yew trees, rose gardens and medicinal plant beds evoking monastic gardens. The paths offer constantly changing perspectives on the ruins.

Fruit Route — The Seine loop between Jumièges and Duclair crosses orchards producing Norman apples. Cider producers welcome visitors for tastings. The blossoming in April transforms the landscape into a white and pink sea.
Seine Loop Hike — A 15-kilometer circuit around the Jumièges peninsula offers panoramas of the abbey, forests and the river. The GR2 follows the banks through orchards and Norman villages.

Brotonne Forest — This 7,000-hectare state forest covering the Seine loop offers 250 kilometers of hiking and mountain biking trails. Centuries-old beeches and oaks create a canopy sheltering fallow deer and roe deer.

Brotonne Bridge — This cable-stayed bridge inaugurated in 1977 spans the Seine with a central span of 320 meters. Its height allows the passage of cargo ships sailing upriver to Rouen. An emblematic structure of Norman engineering.

Vieux-Port Viewpoint — This high point in the Brotonne Forest offers a panorama of the Seine meandering through forests and meadows. Picnic tables allow you to appreciate the peacefulness of the river valley.

days_plan.itin_title: Marseille to Cassis: A Coastal Drive to the Best Calanques & Villages

visits.text: Chic village.
Saint-Jean-Baptiste Church.
The Fier Gorges form a spectacular canyon carved by the river of the same name. A walkway suspended 25 meters above the torrent follows walls sculpted by erosion.
Faces in the rock naturally appear in the limestone walls. Visitors' imagination discerns human profiles and animal silhouettes.
Montrottier Castle dominates the valley from its rocky promontory. This medieval fortress houses collections of antique weapons, faiences, and art objects from around the world.
The castle's circular keep offers a panoramic view of the gorges and surrounding mountains. Vaulted rooms preserve monumental fireplaces.
Menthon-Saint-Bernard Castle stands on a spur overlooking the lake. This fairy-tale residence allegedly inspired Walt Disney's Sleeping Beauty Castle.
Still inhabited by the same family for a thousand years, the castle opens its furnished rooms to visitors. The library holds over 12,000 antique volumes.
La Clusaz displays its authentic Savoyard village at the foot of the Aravis range. Wooden chalets and a pointed church steeple compose a postcard setting.
The Aravis Pass peaks at 1,486 meters offering a grandiose panorama of Mont Blanc on clear days. The winding road crosses pastures and fir forests.
The Balme, Torchère, and Fernuy cirques carve into the massif with their hanging valleys. These natural amphitheaters shelter remarkable alpine flora.
The Burgeat Waterfall tumbles down rocks in the Manigod Valley. A short forest trail leads to this refreshing curtain of water.
The Sulens chalet perched in the alpine meadow welcomes hikers with its farmhouse cheeses. Cows graze the rich grass that gives Reblochon its incomparable taste.

activities.text: Packrafting allows descending the Fier Gorges by water in May and June. This inflatable craft weaves between rocks and rapids.
The 430 steps leading to the gorges' ice cave offer an athletic challenge rewarded by underground coolness.
Visit Menthon Castle during summer evening tours when candles and torches recreate the medieval atmosphere.
Menthon Castle's Christmas market transforms the courtyard into an enchanted village with chalets, ice rink, and mulled wine.
Taste PDO farmhouse Reblochon made in the Aravis alpine pastures. This raw-milk cheese is enjoyed aged or melted in tartiflette.
The Thônes via ferrata offers an aerial route on the cliffs. Ladders, monkey bridges, and footbridges provide vertiginous sensations.
Hiking trails crisscross alpine meadows where herds graze. The climb to the Aravis Pass rewards walkers with an unforgettable panorama.
In summer, ski lifts transport mountain bikers to the summits for descents through flowering alpine meadows.

days_plan.itin_title: Lozère's Remote France: Gorges du Tarn, Aubrac Plateau & Cévennes

visits.text: Verdon Gorges.
Route des Crêtes.

La Palud-sur-Verdon is the characteristic village nestled at the foot of the gorges. Stone houses tier around the Romanesque church. Flowered squares offer refreshing stops in the shade of lime trees.

Point Sublime offers a vertiginous viewpoint over the gorge entrance. The panorama plunges onto the Verdon 180 meters below. It's the starting or arrival point of the Martel trail, depending on the chosen direction.

Viewpoints along the Route des Crêtes follow one another on the clifftop. La Carelle, Tilleul, l'Escalès... each promontory reveals a different facet of the canyon. The setting sun sets the cliffs ablaze in golden and pink hues.

The Maison des Gorges du Verdon presents the canyon's exceptional ecosystem. Interactive exhibitions and documentaries reveal the geology, fauna and flora of this classified natural site. Griffon vultures and golden eagles reign over these walls.

activities.text: Descend the Verdon by kayak from Lac de Sainte-Croix. The boat glides on turquoise waters between canyon walls. Limestone cliffs rise on each side, creating an open-air natural cathedral atmosphere.

Aquatic hikes combine walking and swimming in Verdon tributaries. Jumps into pools, passages under waterfalls and whitewater swimming punctuate the route. Secondary gorges offer an intimate and preserved setting.

Climbing in the gorges attracts climbers from around the world. Over 1500 equipped routes trace their lines on the limestone. Sectors range from 3 to 9, offering challenges for all levels in a spectacular setting.

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral stands atop the hill like stone lacework. Built between 1150 and 1235, it represents one of the first major examples of French Gothic architecture. Sixteen sculpted oxen adorn its towers, recalling the legend of a miraculous ox descended from heaven to transport the stones. The interior displays stunning brightness thanks to tall windows and white limestone.

Climb the 209 steps of the tower to reach the lapidary museum installed in the galleries. This unique deposit in France displays about a hundred carved stones dating from the construction and 19th-century restoration. Gargoyles, capitals and medieval sculptures reveal themselves up close. The panorama over the upper town and surrounding plains rewards the ascent.

Explore the medieval underground passages with audio guide for a one-hour visit through the network of galleries dug beneath the city. These former quarries transformed into cellars tell the geological and political history of Laon. The new scenography recently inaugurated transforms the discovery into a true time journey under the crowned city.

The medieval ramparts encircle the upper town for several kilometers. Discover the fortified gates, notably the Ardon gate, and admire the sweeping view over the Axonais countryside. The walls punctuated with towers testify to Laon's strategic past.

activities.text: Wander through the cobblestone streets of the medieval upper town. Half-timbered houses line the narrow streets, including the oldest house in Laon with its round chimneys in the Pourrier alley. Private mansions and inner courtyards reveal themselves as you stroll.

The Euromédiévales bring the ramparts to life each year with shows, period craftsmen and activities for the whole family. The festival plunges the city into a medieval atmosphere during a festive weekend.

visits.text: Eu Castle — This 16th-century brick and stone castle was the summer residence of King Louis-Philippe from 1830 to 1848. Its apartments preserve Second Empire furniture and decor. The park of 22 hectares includes a French garden and an English garden.

Saint-Laurent Collegiate Church of Eu — This 12th-16th century Gothic church shelters the crypt where the counts of Eu rest, including the Guise princes. Its flamboyant portal and Renaissance statues testify to four centuries of construction.

Le Tréport Funicular — This 1908 funicular climbs the 100-meter cliff in 3 minutes. The upper station offers a breathtaking panorama of the Bresle estuary, Mers-les-Bains and its Belle Époque villas. An emblematic experience of the resort.

Port of Le Tréport — This fishing port welcomes a fleet of about thirty trawlers. The daily fish auction and the port restaurants offer freshly caught scallops, sole and herring. The quays provide a close view of fishing boats.

activities.text: Mers-les-Bains — Neighboring seaside resort on the Picardy coast, Mers-les-Bains displays 300 Belle Époque villas with polychrome facades classified as historical monuments. Their carved wooden balconies, bay windows and ceramics form a unique architectural ensemble.
Le Tréport Beach — This pebble beach bordered by cliffs has welcomed Parisians since the arrival of the train in 1873. Colorful beach cabins and seafood restaurants perpetuate the bathing tradition.

Saint-Jacques Church of Le Tréport — This 15th-16th century flamboyant Gothic church dominates the port with its massive silhouette. Its pendant keystones and Renaissance porch testify to the port's prosperity in the Middle Ages.

visits.text: Lurs — village on a balcony above a vast olive grove (AOC Aglandau).
Promenade des Évêques and viewpoints over the Durance.

The perched village of Lurs clings to its rocky spur dominating the Durance valley. Medieval streets wind between carefully restored stone houses. The former episcopal city has preserved its medieval character and peaceful atmosphere.

The Bishops' Promenade follows the clifftop ridge. The shaded path offers plunging views over the Durance plain and Pre-Alps. Fifteen oratories mark this spiritual route laid out by Sisteron bishops in the 18th century.

Notre-Dame-de-Vie chapel stands at the village entrance. The 12th-century Romanesque building dominates the landscape with its austere silhouette. The sculpted portal and decorated modillions testify to Provençal builders' craftsmanship.

Discover artists' and artisans' workshops installed in the village. Sculptors, ceramists and painters have occupied former residences. Their creations reflect inspiration drawn from this preserved and luminous setting.
The Lurs seminary occupies a vast monastic complex. 19th-century buildings now house a cultural and training center. Terraced gardens offer a panoramic view over the valley.

activities.text: "Characters and typography" trail (Rencontres de Lure, graphic heritage).
Tasting of local olive oils (neighboring estates).
Hiking trails crisscross hills around Lurs. The route loops through Aleppo pines and pubescent oaks. Viewpoints follow one another over the Durance, Valensole plateau and distant Alpine summits.
The Bishops' Promenade extends through the botanical trail. Educational panels present Mediterranean flora. Thyme, rosemary, wild lavender and cistus perfume the path overlooking the valley.

Admire the panorama from the village's multiple viewpoints. The view embraces the Durance valley, Haute-Provence plateaus and first Alpine foothills. Sunsets set the landscape ablaze with exceptional light.

Lyon: Old Lyon (UNESCO), Saint-Jean Cathedral and Renaissance districts.
Lyon: Notre-Dame de Fourvière basilica and belvedere.
Lyon: Presqu'île, Place Bellecour and the Rhône/Saône quays.
Annecy Castle and Castle Museum
Lake Annecy and promenade des Amours
Cours Mirabeau in Aix-en-Provence
Saint-Sauveur Cathedral in Aix-en-Provence

Old Lyon unfolds between the Saône and Fourvière hill, forming the largest Renaissance quarter in Europe after Venice. The traboules, these covered passages crossing buildings, allowed silk workers to transport fabrics sheltered from bad weather. The Renaissance facades, inner courtyards, and spiral staircases create a unique architectural ensemble listed as UNESCO World Heritage. Rue Saint-Jean and its shops, Place du Change and its old bank, testify to past commercial prosperity.

Fourvière Basilica, perched on its hill, dominates Lyon like a wedding cake. Built in the late 19th century in Romano-Byzantine style, it fascinates with golden mosaics, marble columns, and exceptional stained glass windows. The crypt, as richly decorated as the upper church, houses remarkable ex-votos. The esplanade offers breathtaking panoramic views of the entire city, from Croix-Rousse to Confluence.

The Gallo-Roman theaters of Fourvière, built in the 1st century BC, rank among the oldest in France. The great theater could accommodate 10,000 spectators, while the odeon served more intimate performances. Excavations revealed sophisticated stage sets and audience organization. Summer evening performances recreate ancient magic. The attached Lugdunum Museum presents exceptional collections of objects found on site.

The Croix-Rousse district, former stronghold of canuts (silk workers), climbs steep slopes north of the city center. Tall buildings with huge windows once housed weaving looms. Traboules allowed workers to go from workshop to market without climbing stairs. Today, the neighborhood vibrates with artists, craftsmen, and designers who perpetuate creative spirit. The Gros Caillou belvedere offers spectacular views of the city.

activities.text: Bike ride along the Rhône (urban greenway)
Hiking loops around Pérouges (40–150 min depending on trail)
Lyon: self-guided tour through the traboules (historic passages).
Walk along the banks of the Rhône and Saône

Discover Lyon's famous bouchons, these traditional restaurants serving Lyonnais gastronomy. Quenelles, pike perch, sausage with pistachios, tablier de sapeur accompany Beaujolais and Côtes du Rhône wines. Authentic bouchons, recognizable by their checkered tablecloths and regional dishes, perpetuate ancestral recipes. The warm atmosphere and hearty portions embody Lyonnais conviviality.

Visit Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse, temple of local gastronomy where the greatest chefs source supplies. Fifty artisan vendors offer exceptional products: Bresse chickens, mountain cheeses, regional charcuterie, artisanal chocolates. The festive atmosphere and quality products make this visit an immersion into French culinary art. Tastings allow discovery of unique flavors.

Cruise the Rhône or Saône to discover Lyon from the water. The perspective on quays, bridges, and monuments completely changes the city's perception. Commentary reveals river history and evolution of neighborhoods. Lunch or dinner cruises offer a romantic experience combining gastronomy and sightseeing. Night cruises showcase illuminated buildings.

Explore the Confluence district, this futuristic neighborhood where the Rhône and Saône meet. Contemporary architecture contrasts with historic city: Confluence Museum by architects Coop Himmelb(l)au, the Orange Cube, Nuage towers. The renovated docks, green spaces, and aquatic promenade create a pleasant living environment. The transformation of this former industrial port illustrates Lyon's urban renewal.

visits.text: The historic center displays its winding streets between two medieval gates. Porte Saunerie and Porte Soubeyran guard the fortified old town entrance. Renaissance mansions reveal their inner courtyards and spiral staircases behind heavy wooden doors.

The Jean Giono Center celebrates the local-born writer. The birthplace and urban trail trace the life and work of the author. Manuscripts, original editions and personal objects evoke the universe of the one who sang of Provence and its inhabitants.

Saint-Sauveur church blends Provençal Romanesque and southern Gothic. The 14th-century sculpted portal precedes a nave with soaring vaults. Side chapels house Baroque altarpieces and Renaissance baptismal fonts.
The Présentation convent occupies a vast monastic complex. Terraced gardens offer a green break in the city center. The Baroque chapel displays its gilded stuccoes and restored frescoes.

Discover shaded squares where fountains and washhouses murmur. Place de l'Hôtel de Ville brings Manosque's heart to life. Café terraces invite observing the daily animation of this authentic Provençal town.

activities.text: The Route Napoléon crosses Manosque on the Emperor's historic route. The itinerary follows Bonaparte's footsteps during his return from the island of Elba in 1815. Commemorative markers and panels mark this mythical route between Golfe-Juan and Grenoble.

The Valensole plateau extends at Manosque's gates. Lavender fields draw their fragrant geometry from June to July. Perched villages and distilleries punctuate country roads through this iconic landscape.
Hiking trails crisscross wooded hills around Manosque. Mont d'Or offers a moderate ascent rewarded by a panorama over the Durance and Luberon. Aleppo pines and kermes oaks punctuate the routes.

The Bastion, a 17th-century fortress perched at the water's edge, was the first place dedicated to the artist's work.
Climb to the Old Château Cemetery: terraced levels offer spectacular views over ochre rooftops and the glittering Mediterranean.
The market stalls of Les Halles overflow with flavors: creamy cheeses, fragrant tapenades, golden olive oil, and the famous Menton lemon in all its forms.
Menton — colorful old town (alleyways, stairs) up to Saint-Michel basilica and panoramic terrace over the bay.

days_plan.itin_title: Essonne, France: A Rural Escape Road Trip to Castles & Secluded Valleys

visits.text: Saint-Étienne Cathedral displays its 6,500 m² of stained glass windows, an absolute record in France ahead of Chartres' 2,600 m². Nicknamed the 'Good Lord's Lantern', it bathes in changing light where Marc Chagall's mystical blues dialogue with Hermann de Münster's medieval windows. Its naves rise 42 meters under vault, France's third highest. Between 1958 and 1970, Chagall created stained glass windows inspired by the Old Testament for the ambulatory and north transept, featuring the Sacrifice of Isaac and Jacob's Dream in tones of supernatural blue, cosmic green, and mystical red.

Centre Pompidou-Metz emerges like a spaceship set down on the landscape, with its hexagonal roof of 8,500 m² in woven wood inspired by a Chinese hat. Designed by Japanese architect Shigeru Ban and Jean de Gastines, inaugurated in 2010, it deploys 5,000 m² of exhibition spaces under a structure of 18 km of glued laminated beams. Its spire rises to 77 meters, a nod to the year 1977 when the Paris Centre Pompidou was created. The 15-meter-wide galleries frame views of the cathedral, the train station, and the Seille park.

Place Saint-Louis, the 13th-century medieval arcades draw a setting of blond stone where the footsteps of money changers and Lombard merchants still echo. Half-timbered facades and wrought-iron signs tell eight centuries of international trade. Take time for a coffee under the vaults, where the city of Metz has been beating since the Middle Ages.

The Temple Neuf, a neo-Romanesque Protestant church built between 1901 and 1904 on a small island in the Moselle, is reflected in the waters with its twin 58-meter spires. Erected during the German annexation, it illustrates the Wilhelminian will to mark the urban landscape. Gray sandstone facades, copper roofs turned green, and stained glass windows by Wilhelm Pfeffer create a romantic decor. The interior, restored after World War II, displays Rhine Romanesque architecture.

The Saint-Pierre-aux-Nonnains church, built in the 4th century, is one of the oldest religious buildings in France. Originally a Gallo-Roman basilica then a Benedictine church, it preserves walls 1,600 years old. The nave, austere with exposed stones, evokes late Antiquity. Archaeological excavations revealed Roman mosaics and Merovingian foundations. The building now houses exhibitions and concerts, its millennial acoustics attracting musicians.

activities.text: Stroll through the German Imperial Quarter, an architectural laboratory built between 1902 and 1918 under Wilhelm II. Avenue Foch lines up its neo-Romanesque and Art Nouveau villas with polychrome facades, while the monumental 1908 train station in gray sandstone evokes Rhine castles with its 40-meter central tower. This kaleidoscope of Wilhelminian styles offers a unique immersion in Prussian urbanism of the Belle Époque, with over 800 listed buildings.

The Musée de la Cour d'Or unveils 2,000 years of Metz history in the former Petits Carmes convent. 1st-century Gallo-Roman baths, Roman mosaics, and Romanesque sculptures dialogue under centuries-old vaults. The Merovingian collections are among the richest in France, with the treasure from the Metz-Sablon necropolis. Don't miss the medieval Greniers de Chèvremont integrated into the route.

Take a boat cruise on the Moselle to admire Metz's architecture from the water. The 1-hour routes pass under medieval bridges (Moyen Pont, Pont des Roches), along the cathedral and the Temple Neuf, and the imperial port district. Commentary explains the city's 3,000-year history. Evening cruises at sunset offer a romantic atmosphere. Departures from the port quays April to October.

Explore the covered market of Metz, a metallic structure from 1831 renovated in 2007. The 40 stalls offer regional products: Lorraine mirabelle plums, Munster cheese, Metz sausages, and local wines. Butchers, fishmongers, bakers, and produce sellers perpetuate artisanal traditions. The central square hosts a market on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings. The wrought iron and glass architecture evokes 19th-century Les Halles.

visits.text: The village of Eze clings to its rocky peak at 429 meters altitude: pass through the medieval gate and lose yourself in alleys where time has stopped.
The Exotic Garden of Eze crowns the castle ruins: century-old cacti, rare aloes, contemporary sculptures, and vertiginous views over the Mediterranean.
Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption Church raises its 19th-century bell tower at the heart of the village, with a luminous Baroque interior.
Monaco Rock displays its 16th to 18th-century alleyways: ramparts, the Visitation Chapel, and the cathedral where the Grimaldi princes rest.
The Prince's Palace has dominated the Mediterranean since 1297: witness the changing of the carabinieri, a ceremony run like clockwork.
The Oceanographic Museum plunges into the abyss: 6,000 marine species, the Lagoon recreates a living coral reef at the museum's heart.
The Monte Carlo Casino sparkles with Belle Époque splendor: Charles Garnier signed this masterpiece in 1879, a sumptuous theater-opera inside.

activities.text: Descend the Nietzsche Path: 2 kilometers of steep trail connect the perched village to Eze-sur-Mer, where the philosopher used to meditate.
Eze perfumeries open their workshops: copper stills, manufacturing secrets, fragrant boutiques.
Stroll through Monte-Carlo: sumptuous villas, towering buildings, the Hermitage Hotel, giant yachts in the port.
The Princess Grace Rose Garden blooms with thousands of roses: a peaceful haven dedicated to the memory of the actress who became princess.
Swim at Larvotto beach, fine sand and crystal-clear waters at the foot of Monte-Carlo's buildings.

Mont-Saint-Michel — Abbey (visit)
Mont-Saint-Michel — museums & viewpoints over the bay

Ascend to the magnificent Abbey of Mont-Saint-Michel, one of medieval Europe's most extraordinary architectural achievements and a UNESCO World Heritage masterpiece. This Benedictine abbey represents a stunning fusion of religious and military architecture, with its soaring Gothic spires, Romanesque crypts, and the ethereal cloister known as La Merveille suspended between heaven and earth. The abbey remains an active spiritual site where monastic communities continue daily prayers.

Lose yourself in the enchanting medieval streets that wind their way up the rocky mount toward the abbey summit. These atmospheric lanes, flanked by historic timber-framed houses and ancient stone buildings, create an authentic journey through centuries of pilgrimage history. Each turn reveals architectural treasures, from weathered doorways to tiny chapels tucked into rocky alcoves.

Walk the ancient ramparts encircling Mont-Saint-Michel for unforgettable views of the ever-changing bay. The Terrasse de l'Ouest offers particularly spectacular vistas where you can witness the dramatic interplay of light, tide, and sky that has captivated visitors for over a millennium. These defensive walls tell stories of the mount's military past when it successfully resisted English sieges during the Hundred Years' War.

activities.text: Guided crossing of the bay (according to tide schedules).

Explore the fascinating museums within the mount that reveal different facets of its rich history through carefully curated collections of religious artifacts, historical maquettes, and archaeological discoveries. These intimate exhibitions provide deeper understanding of the spiritual, architectural, and cultural significance of this extraordinary site.

Discover the Couesnon Dam, an innovative hydraulic engineering marvel that has restored the maritime character of Mont-Saint-Michel. This elegant contemporary structure harnesses tidal forces to flush accumulated sediments from around the mount, while also serving as a dramatic architectural gateway and public viewpoint on the approach to the island.

Experience the magical evening atmosphere during summer nocturnal visits to the abbey, when subtle lighting transforms the ancient stones into a dreamscape of shadows and illumination. These special after-dark explorations, accompanied by classical music concerts throughout the year, reveal the monument's mystical essence in an entirely new dimension.

visits.text: The MuPop (Museum of Popular Music) occupies a 15th-century castle offering unique museography dedicated to music from 1750 to today. Interactive exhibits present instruments, sound recordings and music evolution through eras. Collections illustrate mechanical music, accordions, vielles à roue and popular instruments. Multimedia stations invite experimenting with sounds and rhythms.

The Dukes of Bourbon castle (end 13th-beginning 14th centuries) dominates old city with its massive keep and fortified walls. This medieval fortress converted into residential palace illustrates Bourbon power evolution. The courtyard reveals Gothic architecture while some rooms still display period murals. The castle houses the MuPop.

The Saint-Pierre church (12th-15th centuries) combines Romanesque and Gothic in imposing architecture. The carved portal displays remarkable medieval stonework. Interior shelters stained glass windows and carved capitals testifying to religious art development over the centuries. The massive bell tower marks the city skyline.

Old Montluçon unfolds its paved streets and medieval alleys around the castle. Stone and half-timbered houses from 15th to 18th centuries line picturesque streets. Place Notre-Dame and Rue Grande concentrate merchant facades and artisan shops. The medieval city preserves authentic character.

activities.text: The Wilson esplanade and jardins extends in the city center offering green spaces and playgrounds. Paths wind among flowerbeds, century-old trees and fountains. The bandstand hosts concerts during summer. A pleasant place for walks and family breaks.

The Tronçais Forest 25km from Montluçon offers hiking, biking and nature discovery. Marked trails explore exceptional oak forests planted in 17th century. The forest includes ponds, glades and remarkable trees like the Stebbing Oak 300 years old. Perfect for outdoor activities and tranquility.

visits.text: The CNCS (National Center for Stage Costume and Scenography) displays over 10,000 costumes in an exceptional collection illustrating three centuries of performing arts. Former 18th-century barracks transformed into a modern museum present costumes worn by Nureyev, Pavlova or Caruso. Temporary exhibitions unveil backstage secrets and creations by major designers like Christian Lacroix and Yves Saint Laurent.

The Notre-Dame Cathedral, built between 15th and 19th centuries, shelters a masterpiece: the Moulins Master Triptych (circa 1498-1499). This flamboyant Gothic painting depicting the Virgin in Glory with donors Pierre II of Bourbon and Anne of France ranks among French Gothic art masterpieces. The central panel dazzles with colors and refined details characteristic of Franco-Flemish style.

The Anne de Beaujeu Museum occupies a ducal pavilion (late 15th century), testimony to the Dukes of Bourbon's power. Archaeological collections trace the region from prehistory to Middle Ages. The fine arts section displays paintings from 15th to 20th centuries including works by the Moulins Masters. Decorative arts reveal ceramic, sculpture and furniture treasures.

The Jacquemart belfry (15th century) stands out with its 46-meter-high square tower topped by a wrought-iron campanile. Since 1651, three jacks strike the hours: Jacquemart the father, his wife Jacquette added in 1655, and their children in 1774. Climb the 106 steps to enjoy a panorama over the city and Allier valley.

The old Moulins unfolds its cobblestone streets between half-timbered houses and Renaissance mansions. Rue d'Allier and Place d'Allier concentrate bourgeois facades from the 15th to 18th centuries. The Mal Coiffée tower, remnant of the ducal castle razed by Richelieu, overlooks the city from its 38 meters.

activities.text: Stroll along Allier quays converted into a promenade with playgrounds and green spaces. Pedestrian paths invite riverside walks with views of the river and surrounding nature. The proximity to city center allows combining urban visits and outdoor relaxation.

The Saturday morning market fills Place d'Allier with stalls offering regional products, Bourbonnais cheeses, farm poultry and seasonal vegetables. Local producers present their specialties while craftsmen exhibit traditional know-how. The atmosphere is lively and authentic.

Moustiers-Sainte-Marie — village classified among the most beautiful in France, famous for its earthenware and its star suspended between two rocky peaks.

Village of Moustiers-Sainte-Marie clinging to the cliff face, Provençal facades and streets
Climb to Notre-Dame de Beauvoir chapel on the cliff face
Earthenware museum tracing local craftsmanship
Faience workshops.

Climb up to Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir chapel watching over the village. The 262 steps wind through oratories adorned with earthenware tiles. The 12th-century Romanesque sanctuary dominates Moustiers rooftops and offers a plunging view over Lac de Sainte-Croix.

The golden star suspended between two cliffs has intrigued since the 10th century. The 135-meter chain carries this mystical symbol above the village. According to legend, knight de Blacas had it suspended in gratitude to the Virgin Mary after his release from the crusades.

The Earthenware Museum traces the history of this craft renowned throughout Europe. Over 300 exceptional pieces from the 17th and 18th centuries reveal the evolution of designs and techniques. The pharmacy goat signed by Clérissy in 1687 is the collection's jewel.

Earthenware workshops perpetuate centuries-old know-how. Seven workshops open their doors to visitors. Throwing, glazing and painting traditional bird motifs unfold before your eyes respecting ancestral methods.

The Notre-Dame de l'Assomption church displays its 12th-century Lombard bell tower. The Romanesque interior houses an altar carved from a 5th-century sarcophagus. 18th-century organs and gilded altarpieces enrich this historic monument.
Stroll through cobbled streets where the Riou torrent cascades. Fountains murmur at the corners of flowered squares. Ochre facades and vaulted passages compose a Provençal postcard scene.

activities.text: Ascent to Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir (stairway) and belvedere overlooking Lake Sainte-Croix.
Tour of earthenware workshops/boutiques and walk to the Rion waterfalls.
Visit to an earthenware workshop and artisan demonstration.
Hike to the chapel of Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir (panoramic view of Lake Sainte-Croix).
Hike to the Notre-Dame-de-Beauvoir chapel for a view over the lake and the Verdon Gorges.
Discovery of earthenware workshops and shops (14 workshops and 22 stores).
Walk around the Rion waterfall or towards the Sainte-Madeleine cave.
Viewpoint of the star suspended above the village and the landscapes around the Verdon

The Valensole plateau unfolds its lavender fields as far as the eye can see from June to July. Purple rows undulate to the horizon in a fragrant ocean. Country roads cross this iconic landscape where lavandin blue contrasts with the Provençal sky.

Visit a traditional distillery where lavender essence is extracted. Copper stills transform freshly cut flowers into essential oil. The aroma fills stone buildings where bouquets once dried. Discover derivative products and natural cosmetics.

The Friday morning Provençal market brings Place Montelupo to life. Local producers offer goat cheeses, lavender honey, olives and olive oil. The colorful and fragrant atmosphere evokes authentic Provençal terroir.

Lac de Sainte-Croix extends its turquoise waters over 2200 hectares. Equipped beaches invite swimming in this artificial lake with lagoon-like appearance. Pedal boats, canoes and electric boats rental to explore the shores and the Verdon gorge entrance.

visits.text: Nantua nestles in a spectacular mountain pass, hemmed between vertiginous limestone cliffs and its emerald-green glacial lake.
Saint-Michel Abbey Church is the most important Romanesque building in the Ain department. Elder sister of Cluny, it preserves a Delacroix painting depicting the Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian.
Sculpted marble angels keep watch in the Romanesque and Gothic choir. The classified organ resounds during concerts that enliven the thousand-year-old nave.
The Museum of Resistance and Deportation bears witness to the commitment of the Ain maquis. This memorial honors the freedom fighters.
Stroll through the Pierre quarter where medieval shops line narrow alleyways. The Doye spring gushes forth right in the town center.
The Lâte Tower stands as the last remnant of the ramparts that once encircled the town. From its battlements, the view embraces the lake and cliffs.

Nantua nestles along the shores of a glacial lake enclosed in a mountain cirque. The town developed around its Benedictine abbey founded in the 8th century. The lake, 2.7 kilometers long and 650 meters wide, offers enchanting landscapes with mountains reflected in calm waters. Nantua also played a crucial role during the Resistance, serving as a refuge for many maquis fighters.

The Abbey Church of Saint-Michel, rebuilt in the 19th century in neo-Romanesque style, stands out with its two asymmetrical bell towers. The interior houses an exceptional collection of religious art including a monumental wooden altarpiece and remarkable stained glass windows. The crypt preserves vestiges of the primitive abbey dating from the 8th century. The building's history intertwines with that of the town over twelve centuries.

The Resistance and Deportation Museum pays tribute to Bugey maquis fighters who fought Nazi occupation. The collections present period documents, weapons, personal objects, and moving testimonies. Reconstituted scenes recreate daily life of clandestine fighters in the mountains. A section is dedicated to local heroes deported to concentration camps. The visit, both educational and emotional, keeps alive the memory of these dark years.

Walk along the lake on the promenade offering spectacular views of surrounding mountains. The tree-lined path connects beaches, picnic areas, and belvederes. Lakeside cafés invite you to enjoy quenelles de Nantua, local specialty with crayfish sauce, while admiring the landscape. Children's play areas and pétanque courts attract families. The peaceful atmosphere and natural beauty make this walk a privileged moment.

activities.text: The turquoise lake invites swimming, canoeing, and paddleboarding. The limpid waters reflect the limestone cliffs that frame it.
Taste authentic quenelles with Nantua sauce, a specialty born on the lake shores. Pike and red-clawed crayfish once made this recipe famous.
Each autumn, the Quenelle Festival celebrates this local specialty in a gourmet and festive atmosphere.
Pair your meal with a glass of Bugey-Cerdon, the sparkling rosé wine produced just a few kilometers away in neighboring hillsides.

Taste the famous quenelles de Nantua, this pike dumpling topped with crayfish sauce that made the town's culinary reputation. Local restaurants all offer their version of this emblematic dish. The original recipe, jealously guarded, dates back several centuries. Some establishments open their kitchens to show preparation of this technical dish. The delicate texture and rich sauce delight fine palates.

Swim or practice water sports on the lake. The supervised beaches offer safe swimming in summer. Canoe, kayak, and paddleboard rentals allow exploration of hidden coves. Fishing enthusiasts can catch pike, perch, and trout. Pedalos invite families to gentle cruises while admiring mountain landscapes. The clear, fresh water delights swimmers.

Hike the Tour du Lac trail, an 8 km loop offering varied perspectives on water and mountains. The marked path alternates between lakeside sections and wooded passages. Belvederes reveal panoramic views of the cirque and town. The gentle slopes make this walk accessible to everyone. Picnic areas invite pauses to fully enjoy the landscape.

Visit during Fête du Lac in August, when the town celebrates summer with fireworks reflected in calm waters. The entire lakefront comes alive with stands, entertainment, and concerts. Local restaurants offer outdoor tasting menus. The festive atmosphere and spectacular fireworks attract thousands of visitors. The tradition, perpetuated for decades, marks the high point of the summer season.

visits.text: The thermal baths of Néris perpetuate 2000-year-old Gallo-Roman tradition. Ancient thermal springs called "Aquae Nerii" attracted Romans seeking benefits of mineral waters. Current modern facilities treat rheumatism, osteoarthritis and anxiety disorders. The Belle Époque architecture preserves spa resort charm from early 20th century.

The archaeological site reveals Gallo-Roman thermal baths and ancient sanctuary remains. Educational panels explain Roman bathing practices and daily life in ancient spa resort. Excavated vestiges testify to thermal installation importance in antiquity. Free access allows discovering this historical heritage.

The thermal park extends 50 hectares of English gardens around spa facilities. Paths wind among century-old trees, flowerbeds and ponds. The landscaped setting invites strolling and relaxation in green environment. Bandstand and kiosks host summer concerts and events.

The thermal quarter reveals Belle Époque architecture with hotels and villas from early 20th century. Bourgeois facades, balconies and ornate ironwork testify to spa resort splendor. Rue de la République and surrounding streets concentrate period buildings creating nostalgic atmosphere.

activities.text: The Néris casino offers games, slot machines and evening shows in Belle Époque setting. This leisure establishment perpetuates spa resort festive tradition attracting visitors seeking entertainment. Restaurant and bar complete the offer for convivial evening.

Walk around Néris lake discovering beach, nautical base and picnic areas. Water activities include pedal boats, canoes and swimming in summer. Paths around lake offer family strolls in nature close to town center.

visits.text: The Promenade des Anglais stretches 7 kilometers along the Bay of Angels, lined with Belle Époque palaces with pink domes and iconic blue chairs.
Lose yourself in Old Nice: laundry hangs from windows, green shutters clatter against ochre and yellow facades, cool alleyways wind toward secret squares.
The Palais Lascaris reveals its 17th-century Baroque treasures: sumptuous frescoes, gilded woodwork, and a rare collection of ancient musical instruments.
Admire the Sainte-Réparate Cathedral on Place Rossetti, a Baroque jewel of Nice where gilding rivals polychrome marbles.
Climb Castle Hill by staircase or free elevator: a wooded park overlooks the city, a waterfall murmurs, and the view embraces the Bay of Angels all the way to the Alps.
Colorful fishing boats dance on the waters of Port Lympia while red and yellow facades reflect in the basin, between luxury yachts and fishermen's nets.
Discover Place Garibaldi, unique in Europe: its four yellow arcaded facades create a Piedmontese trompe-l'oeil theater.
On Cimiez Hill, Roman arenas sleep beneath century-old olive trees. The Matisse Museum watches from its red villa, the Franciscan monastery offers its peaceful gardens.

visits.text: Medieval city of the Pierres Dorées; towers, gates and spiral alleys.
Upper esplanade: panorama over the Beaujolais mountains.

Oingt, classified among the Most Beautiful Villages of France, unfolds its golden stone houses on a rocky outcrop overlooking the Azergues valley. The medieval village, fortified in the 13th century, has preserved its authentic character with ramparts, fortified gates, and cobbled streets called 'calades.' The golden color of buildings, due to local limestone, creates a unique luminosity particularly magical at sunset. Oingt embodies the quintessence of Golden Stone Country.

The Church of Saint-Mathieu, perched at the village's highest point, offers a panoramic view extending from Mont Blanc to the Pilat massif on clear days. Built in the 12th century in Romanesque style, it houses remarkable religious furniture and frescoes recently restored. The square bell tower serves as a landmark visible from the entire valley. The interior, soberly decorated, invites contemplation.

The medieval castle, though partially ruined, testifies to Oingt's strategic importance during the Middle Ages. The square tower, still standing, dominates the village and offers exceptional views of surrounding landscapes. Guided tours reveal the secrets of medieval defense architecture and daily life of lords. The castle gardens, redesigned according to period principles, showcase plants cultivated in the Middle Ages.

Walk the covered walkways and narrow calades that climb between golden stone houses. Each corner reveals new perspectives on surrounding landscapes: vineyards, forests, and hills unfolding to the horizon. Artisan workshops occupy vaulted cellars: pottery, painting, sculpture. The charming village has attracted many artists seeking authentic beauty.

activities.text: Tour of the ramparts and observation tower (heritage route).
Ridge path: short loop on the dry stone walls.

Discover local wines at winegrowers cultivating hillsides around the village. The terroir of Golden Stones produces fruity and elegant wines, less known than great crus but of remarkable quality. Independent producers welcome visitors to explain their work and passion. Tastings take place in vaulted cellars dug into rock, creating an intimate and authentic atmosphere.

Visit artisan workshops perpetuating traditional know-how: pottery, weaving, painting on stone. Artists draw inspiration from surrounding landscapes and special light of Golden Stones. Some open their workshops for demonstrations and explanations of techniques used. Unique creations reflect the village's soul and beauty of local materials.

Hike the Sentier des Pierres Dorées circuit that crosses vineyards and hamlets. The 8 km marked trail offers spectacular views of the Azergues valley and Mont Blanc in the distance. The route passes through several golden stone villages, each with its own character. Information panels explain geological particularity of local limestone and its influence on architecture.

Attend an outdoor concert during the Music Festival that takes place in July. Church square transforms into an open-air stage where classical, jazz, and world music echo off golden stone walls. The unique acoustics and magical setting make each performance an unforgettable moment. Spectators settle on steps and walls for an immersive musical experience.

visits.text: Bois de Vincennes — Paris's largest green space with 995 hectares, this royal forest landscaped by Haussmann contains four lakes, a racetrack, a velodrome and the award-winning Parc Floral. Its bridle paths and bike trails offer a natural escape at the gates of Paris.

Château de Vincennes — Medieval fortress dominated by Europe's tallest keep (52 meters), this royal castle served as residence to seven kings of France before Versailles. The 14th-century Sainte-Chapelle, replica of Paris's, preserves remarkable Flamboyant Gothic stained glass.

Bercy Village — Former 19th-century wine warehouses converted into a commercial and cultural village, this pedestrian district with original cobblestones houses cinemas, restaurants and boutiques under century-old plane trees. Frank Gehry's Cinémathèque française completes the ensemble.

activities.text: Coulée Verte René-Dumont — World's first elevated linear park (1993) built on the former Bastille railway line, this 4.7 km tree-lined promenade crosses the 12th arrondissement at 10 meters height before descending to the Bois de Vincennes.

Parc Floral de Paris — This 35-hectare botanical garden in the heart of the Bois de Vincennes features over 3,000 plant species around a central pond. Its seasonal flower exhibitions and summer jazz festival make it unmissable.

Bastille Quarter — This historic crossroads where the fortress was stormed on July 14, 1789 now vibrates to the rhythm of trendy bars and clubs on rue de Lappe. Carlos Ott's Opéra Bastille and Port de l'Arsenal add a contemporary cultural touch.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Trocadéro — This monumental esplanade facing the Eiffel Tower offers the most beautiful viewpoint on the Iron Lady from the Palais de Chaillot gardens. Its Trocadéro cascading fountains, created for the 1937 Exhibition, illuminate at dusk in a water show.

Musée Marmottan Monet — This 19th-century private mansion houses the world's largest collection of Claude Monet works, including Impression, Sunrise that gave its name to the Impressionist movement. The monumental Water Lilies and Berthe Morisot collection complete this unique ensemble.

Bois de Boulogne — Former 846-hectare royal hunting ground landscaped by Haussmann, this green lung of western Paris contains two romantic lakes, the Longchamp racecourse, the Auteuil greenhouses and the Bagatelle rose garden with 10,000 rose bushes.

activities.text: Serres d'Auteuil — This 1898 botanical garden houses five tropical greenhouses where palms, orchids and exotic plants thrive under Art Nouveau glass roofs. The Japanese garden with koi carp and century-old azaleas offers an unexpected zen break.

Musée de l'Homme — Set in the Passy wing of the Palais de Chaillot, this museum renovated in 2015 explores human evolution through 700,000 years of history. Its ethnographic and prehistoric collections coexist with reflections on our species' future.

Cité de l'Architecture — World's largest architecture center set in the Palais de Chaillot, this museum presents life-size casts of Romanesque and Gothic portals, models of radiant cities and reconstituted Le Corbusier witness apartment.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Sacré-Cœur Basilica — Built between 1875 and 1914 in Romano-Byzantine style by Paul Abadie, this white stone basilica from Château-Landon rises to 130 meters altitude on Montmartre hill. Its 475 m² mosaic of Christ in Glory is one of the world's largest. Since 1885, perpetual prayer has been maintained day and night.

Village of Montmartre — Former wine-growing village annexed to Paris in 1860, Montmartre has preserved its cobbled lanes, secret stairways and bohemian atmosphere. Picasso, Van Gogh and Toulouse-Lautrec lived there, immortalizing its windmills and cabarets in their works.

Place du Tertre — Artistic heart of Montmartre since the 19th century, this cobbled square gathers painters and portrait artists under umbrellas. Despite tourist crowds, it retains the charm of Belle Époque studios where Utrillo painted white facades.

Montmartre Vineyards — Last wine-growing vestige of Paris planted in 1933 on 1,556 m², this vineyard produces about 500 bottles of Clos Montmartre each year during festive October harvest. A reminder of the wine-growing tradition that once covered the entire hill.

activities.text: Moulin Rouge — Founded in 1889, this legendary red-windmill cabaret saw the birth of the French cancan and hosted Toulouse-Lautrec who immortalized its dancers. Its feathered revues perpetuate the tradition of Parisian music hall in Pigalle.

Fondation Louis Vuitton — Glass vessel conceived by Frank Gehry and inaugurated in 2014 in the heart of the Bois de Boulogne, this contemporary art museum unfolds twelve translucent sails over 46 meters high. Its terraces offer panoramic views of La Défense and Paris.

Palais de Tokyo — Europe's largest contemporary art center with 22,000 m², this 1937 Art Deco palace programs bold exhibitions and performances until midnight. Its Monsieur Bleu restaurant facing the Eiffel Tower attracts creative Paris.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Louvre Museum — Former medieval fortress that became a royal palace then museum in 1793, the Louvre houses over 35,000 works across 60,600 m². The glass pyramid designed by I.M. Pei in 1989 marks the entrance to this temple of art where the Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci, the Venus de Milo and the Winged Victory of Samothrace reign.

Tuileries Garden — Created by Catherine de' Medici in 1564 then redesigned by Le Nôtre in 1664, this French formal garden extends over 23 hectares between the Louvre and Place de la Concorde. Sculptures by Maillol and Rodin punctuate the paths lined with century-old chestnut trees.

Place Vendôme — Jewel of elegance designed by Hardouin-Mansart in 1699, this octagonal square with classical facades houses the world's greatest jewelers. The central column, cast from bronze of 1,200 cannons captured at Austerlitz, rises to 44 meters.

activities.text: Palais Royal — Pass through the arcades to discover Buren's columns in the courtyard of honor and the secret gardens surrounded by galleries where antique dealers and fashion boutiques line up. This haven of peace was the theater of the beginnings of the French Revolution.

Comédie-Française — Founded in 1680 by Louis XIV, the world's oldest theater company perpetuates French dramatic art. Admire the neoclassical facade of the Salle Richelieu where Molière performed his final shows.

Rue de Rivoli Arcades — Stroll under the 2.5 km of Napoleonic arcades lined with shops and cafés. This monumental perspective offers protection from the weather while revealing the uniform facades desired by Percier and Fontaine.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Père-Lachaise Cemetery — Paris's largest necropolis at 44 hectares established in 1804, this garden cemetery with romantic paths houses the graves of Jim Morrison, Édith Piaf, Oscar Wilde, Chopin and Molière. Its neo-Gothic chapels and Art Nouveau mausoleums make it an open-air museum.

Parc de Belleville — This 4.5-hectare park built in 1988 on Paris's highest hill (108 meters) offers an exceptional panorama of the capital from its belvedere terrace. Its waterfalls, playground and Maison de l'Air make it a popular green lung.

Ménilmontant Quarter — This working-class village absorbed by Paris in 1860 preserves its secret passages, artists' studios and authentic bistros. The walls covered in street art and the guinguettes of Parc des Buttes perpetuate its bohemian and creative spirit.

activities.text: Rue Oberkampf — Trendy artery of eastern Paris, this street with colorful facades lines up cocktail bars, world cuisine restaurants and concert venues. In the evening, its giant terrace invades the sidewalks for a festive and cosmopolitan atmosphere.

Street Art in Belleville — The streets of Belleville form an open-air gallery where the greatest names in world street art express themselves. Rue Dénoyez with entirely covered walls and murals on Boulevard de Belleville constantly renew this free urban museum.

Place Gambetta and 20th arrondissement town hall — This working-class neighborhood with village charm is organized around Place Gambetta and its Second Empire town hall. The Belleville market, one of Paris's largest and cheapest, animates its streets on Tuesdays and Fridays.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral — Masterpiece of French Gothic built between 1163 and 1345, the cathedral reopened its doors in December 2024 after five years of restoration following the 2019 fire. Its 12,000 oak timbers of the new framework, its spire rebuilt identical to Viollet-le-Duc's and its restored 13th-century rose windows once again dazzle visitors.

Île de la Cité — Historical cradle of Paris where the Parisii settled in the 3rd century BC, this island houses the vestiges of royal and religious power. Stroll along the Quai des Orfèvres immortalized by Simenon and discover the century-old flower market.

Sainte-Chapelle — Jewel of Rayonnant Gothic erected in just seven years (1241-1248) by Saint Louis to house the Crown of Thorns. Its 1,113 m² of 13th-century stained glass, among the oldest in Paris, diffuse celestial light depicting 1,113 biblical scenes.

activities.text: Place des Vosges — Paris's oldest square inaugurated in 1612, this perfect 140-meter square charms with its red brick and blonde stone pavilions. Victor Hugo lived there for six years at No. 6, now a free museum dedicated to the writer.

Centre Pompidou — Cathedral of modern and contemporary art conceived by Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, inaugurated in 1977. Its "inside-out" architecture exposes colored pipes and escalators on the facade, housing Europe's largest modern art collection.

Musée d'Orsay — Former train station transformed into a temple of Impressionism, the museum displays masterpieces by Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh and Cézanne under a monumental glass roof. The great clock offers a unique view of Montmartre.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Latin Quarter — Paris's intellectual heart since the Sorbonne's founding in 1257, this neighborhood owes its name to Latin spoken by medieval students. Its cobbled lanes lined with bookshops, art cinemas and bistros perpetuate the bohemian and rebellious spirit of May '68.

Panthéon — Commissioned by Louis XV in 1744 as Sainte-Geneviève church then transformed into a republican mausoleum in 1791, this neoclassical temple by Soufflot houses the remains of Victor Hugo, Voltaire, Rousseau, Marie Curie, Jean Moulin and Simone Veil. Foucault's pendulum demonstrated Earth's rotation there in 1851.

La Sorbonne — Founded in 1257 by Robert de Sorbon to train theologians, this legendary university rebuilt under the Third Republic preserves its 17th-century chapel where Cardinal Richelieu rests. Its amphitheaters have seen the greatest thinkers pass through.

Luxembourg Gardens — Created by Marie de' Medici in 1612 to accompany her Florentine palace, this 25-hectare garden blends French and English styles. Its iconic metal chairs, pond where small sailboats glide and statues of French queens make it Parisians' favorite green lung.

activities.text: Latin Quarter Bookshops — Explore the legendary Shakespeare and Company facing Notre-Dame, Gibert Joseph and its seven floors, or the bouquinistes along the Seine quays listed as UNESCO heritage. These temples of books perpetuate the neighborhood's literary tradition.

Boulevard Saint-Germain — This 3 km Haussmannian artery crosses the intellectual heart of the Left Bank where Sartre and Beauvoir philosophized at Café de Flore and Deux Magots. Antique dealers, galleries and publishing houses perpetuate this cultural heritage.

Théâtre de l'Odéon — France's oldest theater inaugurated in 1782, this Italian-style neoclassical hall hosted the premieres of Beaumarchais's The Marriage of Figaro. Now Théâtre de l'Europe, it programs contemporary creations and great classics.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Saint-Germain-des-Prés — Paris's oldest church founded in 543 by Childebert I, this neighborhood was the heart of postwar existentialism. Jazz caves, art galleries and antique dealers perpetuate the bohemian atmosphere dear to Boris Vian and Juliette Gréco.

Saint-Sulpice Church — Paris's second-largest church after Notre-Dame, this 17th-century monument impresses with its asymmetrical facade and two unfinished towers. Its astronomical gnomon and Delacroix frescoes in the Chapel of the Holy Angels fascinate visitors.

Historic Cafés — Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots face each other on Boulevard Saint-Germain, witnesses to 20th-century intellectual ferment. Their heated terraces under red umbrellas perpetuate the tradition of the Parisian philosophical café.

activities.text: Canal Saint-Martin — This romantic 4.5 km canal dug under Napoleon I crosses northeast Paris through nine locks and two swing bridges. Its tree-lined banks, immortalized in the film Amélie, attract picnickers and pétanque players.

Parc des Buttes-Chaumont — This 25-hectare park landscaped by Haussmann in 1867 on former gypsum quarries offers Paris's unique steep terrain. Its Temple of the Sibyl perched on a 50-meter rock dominates the lake and artificial waterfalls.

Montmartre Cemetery — Third-largest Parisian necropolis, this romantic cemetery with shaded paths houses the graves of Dalida, François Truffaut, Edgar Degas and Émile Zola. A peaceful haven overlooked by the Caulaincourt Bridge.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Eiffel Tower — Built in 2 years, 2 months and 5 days by Gustave Eiffel for the 1889 Universal Exhibition, this 330-meter, 7,300-ton "Iron Lady" of puddled steel assembled by 2.5 million rivets was meant to be dismantled after 20 years. Saved by its usefulness for wireless telegraphy, it now welcomes nearly 7 million visitors per year.

Champ-de-Mars — This 780-meter esplanade extends from the Eiffel Tower to the Military School where Bonaparte studied. Former parade ground, this English-style garden hosted five Universal Exhibitions and remains the preferred spot for Parisian picnics facing the Iron Lady.

Hôtel des Invalides — Commissioned by Louis XIV in 1670 to house wounded soldiers, this masterpiece by Libéral Bruant then Hardouin-Mansart houses under its 107-meter golden dome Napoleon I's tomb, in six nested coffins of red quartzite.

activities.text: Musée Rodin — Set in the 18th-century Hôtel Biron where the artist lived, this museum presents The Thinker, The Kiss and The Burghers of Calais in a verdant setting. The sculpture garden is among Paris's most romantic.

Musée du Quai Branly — Designed by Jean Nouvel and inaugurated in 2006, this museum of indigenous arts houses 300,000 objects from Africa, Asia, Oceania and the Americas. Its 800 m² plant wall signed by Patrick Blanc makes it a unique vertical garden.

Place de la Concorde — Paris's largest square where Louis XVI was guillotined in 1793, it displays the Luxor obelisk offered by Egypt in 1836. Its monumental fountains and eight statues representing great French cities frame a unique perspective toward the Champs-Élysées.

days_plan.itin_title: Paris Must-Sees

visits.text: Avenue des Champs-Élysées — Nicknamed "the most beautiful avenue in the world," this 1.9 km artery connecting Concorde to the Arc de Triomphe was laid out by Le Nôtre in 1667. Its wide sidewalks planted with chestnut trees host July 14th military parades and the Tour de France finish.

Arc de Triomphe — Commissioned by Napoleon in 1806, this 50-meter-high monument celebrates the victories of the Grande Armée. The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier's flame has burned there since 1923, rekindled each evening at 6:30 pm. The panoramic terrace offers a 360° view of the twelve radiating avenues.

Grand Palais — Built for the 1900 Universal Exhibition, this Beaux-Arts palace features Europe's largest glass roof covering 13,500 m². Its 45-meter-high nave hosts major international exhibitions and fashion shows from the great houses.

Petit Palais — Harmonious counterpart to the Grand Palais, this City of Paris Fine Arts Museum presents collections from Antiquity to 1914 for free. Its peristyle inner garden, inspired by Pompeii, offers an unexpected bucolic break.

activities.text: Église de la Madeleine — Neoclassical temple surrounded by 52 Corinthian columns 20 meters high, this church without bell tower or cross was desired by Napoleon as a temple to the glory of the Grande Armée. Its richly decorated interior hosts concerts and prestigious ceremonies.

Musée de Cluny — Set in a 15th-century medieval mansion and 3rd-century Gallo-Roman baths, this National Museum of the Middle Ages preserves the famous Lady and the Unicorn tapestry, six 15th-century Flemish tapestries illustrating the five senses and a mysterious sixth.

Arènes de Lutèce — Vestige of the 1st-century Gallo-Roman amphitheater that could hold 15,000 spectators, these arenas rediscovered in 1869 during Haussmann's works now form a peaceful garden where Parisians play pétanque.

visits.text: Medieval city surrounded by ramparts; cobblestone streets, weavers' houses.
Porte d'En Haut and tower, views over the Ain plain.
The fortified village of Pérouges stands atop a hill, surrounded by ramparts pierced by two medieval gates. Over eighty buildings are classified as historic monuments.
Pass through the Upper Gate to enter the town. The fortress-church of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine integrates its outer wall into the ramparts, with the patrol path running at roof level.
The Rue des Rondes encircles the village and reveals the most beautiful mansions: General Messimy's house with mullioned windows, the salt storehouse, and the 15th-century Valensot house.
Explore the House of the Princes on the street of the same name. This 14th and 15th-century dwelling housed representatives of the Dukes of Savoy and now contains the Old Pérouges Museum.
Climb the fifteen-meter-high watchtower to survey the village rooftops and the Ain plain. The hortulus recreates a medieval garden as it existed in the Middle Ages.
The Market Square is organized around the linden tree planted in 1792, called the Tree of Liberty. Half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors create a timeless setting.
Admire the sundial house bearing the motto 'I will only mark the hours of fair days.' The Cazin house opens its doors to curious visitors.

Pérouges, the only Most Beautiful Village of France in Ain, unfolds its cobblestone streets like an intact movie set. The fortified medieval town, perched on its tuff outcrop, has crossed the centuries without losing its soul as a 15th-century weaver village. Eighty historic monuments bear witness to this exceptional heritage, where the powerful Dukes of Savoy once lived.

The Place du Tilleul forms the beating heart of the village, organized around a centuries-old linden tree that has witnessed the daily life of residents for generations. Surrounded by half-timbered houses with overhanging upper floors and carved corbels, the square embodies the charm of medieval architecture. The old well, still visible in the center, recalls the times when water collection organized community life.

The Church of Sainte-Marie-Madeleine overlooks the village with its octagonal bell tower, an unusual architectural feature. Built in the 15th century, it houses remarkable religious furniture and stained glass windows that filter colored light onto the stone walls. The fortified porch served as both a place of worship and defense during troubled times.

Walk along the covered walkway that runs along the ramparts, offering panoramic views of the Dombes plain. The medieval fortifications, partially restored, testify to the strategic role of Pérouges in controlling the Ain valley. The defensive towers and gates, still visible, recall the turbulent era when the village had to protect itself from invasions.

activities.text: Rampart tower and circuit of remarkable houses (2 km).
Peripheral rural path for panorama over Dombes and Bugey.
Pick up the walking trail map at the tourist office for routes winding through the verdant surroundings of the medieval town.
Taste the famous Pérouges sugar galette, a specialty created in the early 20th century whose recipe remains jealously guarded by local artisans.
Enjoy a glass of Cerdon, the sparkling rosé wine from Bugey that perfectly accompanies the region's sweet specialties.

Taste the famous galette de Pérouges, a sweet flat cake with butter and sugar that has become the village's signature dish. The traditional recipe, jealously guarded by local artisans, dates back several centuries. Each bakery offers its version of this golden pastry, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside, best enjoyed warm with a cup of coffee.

Explore the artisan workshops that perpetuate ancestral know-how: weaving, pottery, woodworking. Craftsmen open their doors to explain traditional techniques that made the fortune of this merchant town. Demonstrations of period looms fascinate visitors with the complexity of gestures and the beauty of fabrics produced.

Wander the covered walkways and hidden passages that connect the streets. These shaded spaces, sheltered from bad weather, were used by weavers to protect precious fabrics from moisture. Stone arches and sculpted corbels reveal unsuspected architectural details with each step.

Visit the Museum of Old Pérouges, housed in several period buildings. It presents daily life of medieval inhabitants through reconstructed interiors, work tools, and historical objects. Period costumes, weaving looms, and traditional furniture bring the prosperous past of this 15th-century merchant town to life.

visits.text: The fortified city of Phalsbourg, founded in 1570 by Count Palatine George John I, preserves its 17th-century monumental gates. The French Gate and the German Gate, rebuilt by Vauban in 1680, frame the historic center with their classical stone facades topped by clock towers. The ramparts, partially intact, protected the city during the siege of 1814 when 2,200 defenders resisted 30,000 allied soldiers for 7 months. The military heritage path circles the fortifications.

The Saint-Louis crystal works museum, located 8 km away, presents 430 years of glassmaking excellence. The collections showcase masterpieces: the 1878 Universal Exhibition chandelier, Art Nouveau creations by Emile Gallé, and contemporary pieces by world-renowned designers. Immersive exhibitions explain techniques: blowing, cutting, engraving, gilding. The boutique sells numbered pieces signed by master glassmakers.

activities.text: Visit the Saint-Louis-Arzviller inclined plane, a unique boat lift in Europe. Built between 1965 and 1969, it replaces 17 locks with a 44.55-meter vertical lift traversed in 4 minutes. The 108-meter-long steel tank carries 350-ton boats on rails at a 41% gradient. The visitor center explains the hydraulic and mechanical system. Boat rides available from April to October, approximately 1 hour round trip.

Hike in the Northern Vosges forests around Phalsbourg, with trails leading to sandstone peaks. The Circuit of the Three Borders (12 km) passes by the vestiges of the Lutzelbourg castle perched on a 320-meter cliff, offering a panorama of the Zorn valley. Marked trails, variable difficulty, maps available at the tourist office. Beech and oak forests, typical Vosges sandstone rock formations.

days_plan.itin_title: The Fairytale Alsace Route: A Driving Tour of the 15 Most Beautiful Villages
The Ultimate Guide to Alsace Christmas Markets: Enchanted Winter Villages Itinerary

visits.text: Riez-la-Romaine — ancient remains (temple columns), old baptistery and medieval heart.
Gypsum plasterwork route (molded plaster decorations) on remarkable facades and interiors.
Roman columns.
Museum.

Four Roman columns stand isolated in a field. Remains of a 1st-century ancient temple, they testify to the importance of the Gallo-Roman city of Riez. Gray granite contrasts with surrounding lavender fields, creating a timeless tableau.

The 5th-century Merovingian baptistery is one of France's oldest Christian buildings. The stone octagon houses an immersion baptismal font. Reused Roman columns support the vault of this architectural gem classified as a historic monument.

Walk through old town streets where medieval gates and Renaissance facades follow one another. Porte Ayguières and Porte Sanson from the 14th century guard the fortified town entrance. Fountains and washhouses punctuate shaded squares.
The Clock Tower dominates the central square. The sundial adorns the facade of this former medieval watchtower. Arcades of bourgeois houses shelter shops and craftsmen on the ground floor.

The 16th-century Sainte-Maxime chapel nestles on a hill away from the village. The classified building offers a remarkable example of Provençal religious architecture. The panorama embraces Riez and the Valensole plateau.

activities.text: Heritage loop between private mansions, staircases and sculpted porches.
Walk towards the hills of Val d'Asse (view over plateaus).

The heritage discovery circuit winds through Riez and surroundings. Explanatory panels mark the route between Roman remains, medieval buildings and restored washhouses. Allow two hours for this cultural walk through local history.
Lavender fields surround Riez from mid-June to mid-July. Country roads offer multiple viewpoints over these purple expanses. The heady perfume accompanies walks on foot or by bike across the plateau.

The Wednesday morning weekly market brings Riez center to life. Local producers offer lavender honey, goat cheeses and local products. The Provençal atmosphere is in full swing under the plane trees of the square.

days_plan.itin_title: Northern France Cultural Drive: The Belfries & Flemish Heritage of the Nord Region

visits.text: Rouen — Notre-Dame Cathedral
Rouen — Rue du Gros-Horloge & Place du Vieux-Marché
Rouen Museum of Fine Arts
Museum of Ceramics (earthenware)
Joan of Arc Historical Museum
Old Stock Exchange of Lille
Palace of Fine Arts of Lille
Notre-Dame Cathedral of Strasbourg
Petite France District

Gros-Horloge — This 14th-century Gothic belfry houses one of Europe's oldest astronomical clocks, with a mechanism dating from 1389. The Renaissance arch built between 1527 and 1529 spans the pedestrian street with its 2.50-meter golden dial depicting a 24-ray sun on a star-studded blue background. A single hand points to the hour while a globe indicates the phases of the moon.

Place du Vieux-Marché — It was in this square that Joan of Arc was burned on May 30, 1431. The Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc church, inaugurated in 1979, features bold architecture shaped like an inverted flame and houses the Renaissance stained glass windows from the former Saint-Vincent church destroyed during the war.

Saint-Ouen Abbey Church — A masterpiece of Rayonnant Gothic built between the 14th and 16th centuries, this former Benedictine abbey impresses with its 137 meters length and its 14th-century stained glass windows among the most complete in France. Its grand Cavaillé-Coll organ from 1890 has 64 stops.

Musée Le Secq des Tournelles — Housed in the former 15th-century Saint-Laurent church, this museum unique in the world presents 12,000 pieces of ornamental ironwork from the 3rd to 19th century: signs, locks, grilles, everyday objects testifying to the craftsmanship of master blacksmiths.

Panorama Côte Sainte-Catherine — From this 150-meter hill overlooking the left bank, embrace the entire view of Rouen: the cathedral painted by Monet, the spires of Gothic churches, the meanders of the Seine. The viewpoint immortalized by the Impressionists in the 19th century.

Rouen Cathedral — Monet painted this Gothic masterpiece more than 30 times to capture its changing light. Built between the 12th and 16th centuries, its 151-meter cast-iron spire makes it France's tallest. The Lady Chapel and the tombs of Norman dukes bear witness to eight centuries of history.

Palais de Justice de Rouen — This flamboyant Gothic building from the late 15th century was the seat of the Exchequer of Normandy. Its western facade, ornate with sculpted gables and pinnacles, survived the 1944 bombings. The Salle des Pas Perdus reveals medieval vaults.

Musée des Beaux-Arts de Rouen — This museum founded in 1801 houses a major collection of paintings from the 15th to 21st century. Works by Caravaggio, Velázquez, Monet, Sisley and a room dedicated to Géricault born in Rouen illustrate five centuries of European art.

activities.text: Half-day tour — historic center on foot
Stroll through the cobblestone squares and markets of Rouen

Historial Jeanne d'Arc — Housed in the archbishop's palace where Joan was condemned then rehabilitated, this immersive scenographic journey retraces the destiny of the Maid through testimonies, projections and reconstructions of the 1431 trial.

Rue Eau-de-Robec — This picturesque cobbled street runs along a canal where dyers once washed their fabrics. Its half-timbered houses from the 15th and 16th centuries, restored after the 1944 bombings, plunge the stroller into medieval Rouen.

Jardin des Plantes de Rouen — This 8.5-hectare botanical garden created in 1840 houses more than 5,600 plant species, tropical greenhouses and a rose garden. A green lung in the heart of the city, conducive to strolling among botanical collections and century-old trees.

Aître Saint-Maclou — This unique ossuary from the 16th century is a rare testimony to the plague epidemics. Its half-timbered galleries surrounding a courtyard display macabre sculptures: skulls, bones, gravedigger's tools carved into the beams.

Panorama XXL — This 32-meter-high rotunda hosts giant 360° panoramas. Past exhibitions have transported visitors to ancient Rome, Monet's Rouen or the Amazon. A unique immersive artistic experience in France.

Seine Riverbanks — The redeveloped left bank offers 3 kilometers of walks from the Pierre-Corneille bridge to the Île Lacroix. Guinguettes, floating gardens and barges transformed into cultural venues bring life to the quays.
