visits.text: Ébersviller — Illuminated outdoor nativity scene near Saint-Pierre church (1878).
Boulay-Moselle — Saint-Étienne Church (1782): nativity scene at Mary's altar, remarkable organ.
Longeville-lès-Saint-Avold — Saint-Magne Church (neogothic), restored 1905/06 organ, sculpted stations of the cross.
Saint-Avold — Saint-Nabor Abbey Church: traditional nativity scene (according to period).
Saint-Avold — Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc, Saint-Joseph and Saint-Jean-Bosco Churches: nativity scenes (worship service hours).
Folschviller — Sainte-Barbe Residence: traditional nativity scene (15/12–14/01, 2pm–5pm).
Altviller — Village nativity scene with dressed figurines (patchwork club).

The Saint-Avold American Cemetery and Memorial, inaugurated in 1960, is the largest American World War II cemetery in Europe. On 46 hectares of perfectly maintained lawns, 10,489 white marble crosses and Stars of David align in impeccable symmetry, honoring American soldiers who fell during the liberation of France, Luxembourg, and Germany in 1944-1945. The memorial chapel in Vosges sandstone displays battle maps and the Wall of the Missing with 444 names. An overwhelming place of remembrance.

The Saint-Nabor basilica, built between 1755 and 1764, is a baroque jewel in Vosges sandstone. Its 60-meter bell towers dominate the city, topped by bulbous domes typical of Central Europe. The interior amazes with stucco decorations, gilded woodwork, and trompe-l'oeil frescoes. The main organ, built in 1782 by Jean-Conrad Sauer, is one of the most beautiful baroque organs in Lorraine. The crypt houses the relics of Saint Nabor.

activities.text: Saint-Avold — Urban walk between the abbey church, stained glass windows and neighborhood nativity scenes.
Organ or Christmas carol listening (according to parish schedule).

Visit the Saint-Avold mining museum, installed in the former Merlebach mine. The exhibitions retrace 150 years of coal extraction (1856-2004): miners' equipment, gallery reconstruction, pneumatic tools, and documentation on working conditions. Educational circuit in surface buildings, testimonies from former miners. The mining towers, industrial heritage from the 20th century, dominate the landscape.

Stroll in the Vallon du Parc, a 15-hectare landscaped park surrounding the Château de Beausoleil. Tree-lined paths, ornamental ponds, rose gardens, and century-old trees compose a green setting. Children's playgrounds, picnic areas, and sports facilities. The Baroque-style castle (18th century) houses administrative services. Free access year-round, ideal for family walks.

visits.text: Saint-Martin-Vésubie, nicknamed "the little Switzerland of Nice," opens the gates to Mercantour National Park: 3,600 hectares of forests, peaks exceeding 3,000 meters.
Stroll through the alpine village alleyways: wooden chalets, murmuring fountains, authentic shops at the foot of the mountains.
The Alpha Wolf Center "Le Temps du Loup" reveals pack life: three habitats allow observation of these majestic predators at feeding time.
Continue to the Sanctuary of Madone de Fenestre: this high-mountain pilgrimage site offers spectacular views of Gélas, the highest peak in the Alpes-Maritimes.
Vésubia mountain park offers indoor climbing, indoor canyoning, caving, and wellness facilities year-round.

Alpine wildlife watching: brown trout in the lakes, chamois on the ridges, golden eagles soaring in the pure sky.

The Chapel of the White Penitents shines with Folon's works: mosaics, stained glass, contemporary sculptures in a 17th-century setting.
The Collegiate Church of the Conversion of Saint Paul blends Romanesque and Baroque, sober choir and gilded chapels.
Climb to the 16th-century bastion: panorama of the Baou mountain chain, Mont Chauve, and hinterland hills.
In the cemetery rests Marc Chagall, grave number 152, row C: the painter spent his final years in this village he loved so much.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpilles Region: Twenty-Five Villages and Provençal Heritage

visits.text: The Saint-Pourçain-sur-Sioule vineyard extends over 640 hectares producing AOC wines since 2009. The terroir cultivates unique Tressallier grape, rare white variety found almost exclusively here. Winegrowers perpetuate ancestral tradition dating back to Romans and Middle Ages when Saint-Pourçain wines supplied royal court and popes.

The Vineyard and Wine Museum occupies a renovated old building presenting viticulture history and winemaking techniques. Collections display traditional tools, historical documents and bottles tracing wine evolution over centuries. Educational tours explain Tressallier grape specificity and local terroir characteristics.

The Sainte-Croix church (12th-13th centuries) dominates city with its massive bell tower. Romanesque architecture displays carved capitals and sculpted portal characteristic of period. Interior shelters remarkable stained glass windows and liturgical objects testifying to religious heritage richness.

Old Saint-Pourçain reveals paved streets lined with stone houses (15th-18th centuries) and winegrower residences. The historic center preserves medieval character with narrow streets, small squares and ancient fountains. Stroll discovering facades and details testifying to wine town past prosperity.

activities.text: Wine cellar visits and tastings allow discovering Saint-Pourçain AOC in authentic setting. Winegrowers present their cuvées (whites, rosés, reds) including rare Tressallier expressing limestone terroir. Direct sales and explanations on vineyard work enrich the oenological experience.

Walk along Sioule discovering old mills and wash houses lining the river. Green banks invite peaceful strolls in nature. Footpaths allow exploring valley where water carved picturesque path through limestone.

days_plan.itin_title: Allier Road Trip: Vichy, Thermal Baths and Bourbonnais Bocage

visits.text: The Saint-Quentin Basilica soars with its 83-meter spire. This Gothic masterpiece from the 12th-15th centuries shelters relics of Saint Quentin. The interior dazzles with its luminosity and extraordinary dimensions with a 34-meter high nave. Stained glass windows tell the saint's martyrdom.

Explore the largest Art Deco heritage in France along the architectural circuit. Facades rebuilt after World War I display geometric motifs, bow windows and sculptural decorations characteristic of the 1920s-1930s. The former Manufacture building, town hall and theater illustrate this artistic wealth.

The Antoine-Lécuyer Museum preserves the world's largest collection of pastels by Maurice-Quentin de La Tour. The 18th-century portraitist immortalized personalities of his time in intimate works of stunning realism. The museum also displays Flemish and French paintings from the 15th to 18th centuries.

The Marais d'Isle natural reserve extends over 120 hectares in the heart of the city. Peat bogs, ponds and humid meadows shelter remarkable fauna and flora. A nature trail with interpretation panels runs through this preserved wetland.

activities.text: Walk along the canal and Somme banks. The towpath converted into a promenade invites peaceful strolls through greenery. Pleasure boats and fishing spots enliven this waterfront.

Discover the underground city sheltering 45 kilometers of medieval quarries and wartime refuges. Guided tours reveal this mysterious underground world beneath Saint-Quentin streets. Chalk walls bear witness to centuries of extraction and wartime hiding.

Visit the butterfly conservatory sheltering over a thousand tropical butterflies flying freely in a greenhouse recreating their natural habitat. Exotic plants and warm climate transport visitors to distant lands.

visits.text: The Franciscan monastery emerges at the end of a steep path: France's only Baroque convent, its cloister with Mexican hacienda airs houses 17th-century frescoes depicting Saint Francis.
Push open the door of Saint-Sauveur Church: ornate Baroque decor, monumental columns, an Italian organ from 1847 carried up by mules from Nice.
The alleyways and "pountin" wind between fountain squares and wash houses: vaulted passages, vertiginous staircases, the village seems to tumble into the valley.
Three fortified castles once watched over Saorge, "the lock of the Roya," a stronghold reputed impregnable. Ruins still dominate the village.
Admire the purple lauze rooftops quarried locally: tall colorful houses cascade like a waterfall of stones.

activities.text: Mercantour National Park reveals its treasures: hike to Bronze Age prehistoric engravings, 5,000 years old.
Board the Train des Merveilles on the Nice-Tende line: tunnels, viaducts, vertiginous panoramas, one of France's most beautiful railway sections.
Refresh yourself at the Sémite pool: crystal-clear spring water nestled in a green setting, a secret paradise for swimmers.
Follow the Baroque and historic organ route from village to village: every church in the Roya Valley holds its treasure.
Sit down at one of the village restaurants to savor herb ravioli and Saorge specialties.

days_plan.itin_title: Aquitaine Grand Loop: Medieval Villages, Vineyards and Prehistoric Sites

visits.text: The Peace stained glass window by Marc Chagall, created between 1974 and 1976 for the 13th-century Cordeliers chapel, rises 12 meters high and spans 7.5 meters wide. This is the largest stained glass window ever designed by the artist, a hymn to life and reconciliation in celestial blue tones, emerald green, and flamboyant red. Allegorical figures (tree of life, prophets, animals) intertwine in poetic composition. Natural light animated by 600 m² of glass transforms throughout the day.

The Sarrebourg museum, installed in the former Cordeliers convent, presents Gallo-Roman archaeology and regional collections. Mosaics from the 2nd-3rd centuries, funerary steles, and ceramics attest to Roman Sarrebourg's importance. The medieval section displays sculptures, liturgical furniture, and paintings from the 15th to 18th centuries. The lapidary garden brings together fragments of ancient buildings.

The Sarrebourg canal marina, on the Marne-Rhine canal, offers boat rides and canal cruises. The port hosts 120 pleasure boat berths and welcomes cruise boats. Waterside promenades, nautical activities (canoe, pedal boat), and cycle paths along the canal. The Boat Museum traces the history of canal navigation and traditional trades. Boat rentals available for exploring the canal.

activities.text: Walk in the forest of Sarrebourg, 3,500 hectares of oaks and beeches crisscrossed by 50 km of marked trails. The Sentier des Sources (8 km) discovers the springs feeding the Sarre, with footbridges over streams and forest clearings. The Lorraine sandstone peaks offer panoramic views. Medium difficulty, 2h30 walking, signposting and maps at the tourist office.

Explore the historic center where the Saint-Barthélémy church (18th century) displays baroque altarpieces and an 18th-century organ. The pedestrian streets preserve 18th and 19th-century bourgeois houses. The Place du Marché, surrounded by arcaded facades, hosts a market on Tuesday and Friday mornings. The town hall (1770) in classical style faces the park with centuries-old trees.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The Faience Museum occupies the former Moulin de la Blies, reconstructed in 2007 around the listed 1880 Winter Garden. This 750 m² metal and glass structure shelters 2,500 pieces tracing 200 years of ceramic production: earthenware services, decorative panels, Art Nouveau vases, and Art Deco creations. The collections present the evolution of techniques and styles from 1790 to the 1990s, when the last Sarreguemines kilns shut down.

The Casino des Faïenceries, an Art Nouveau jewel from 1927, amazes with its ceramic decorations: mosaics, friezes, and monumental panels by master ceramist Alexandre Sandier. The grand hall, completely covered in earthenware, evokes Sarreguemines' golden age when 3,000 workers produced 25 million pieces per year. The building now houses temporary exhibitions on ceramic history and industrial heritage.

The Faience Garden (Jardin des Faïenciers) displays monumental ceramic panels in an 8,000 m² landscaped park. The route presents 150 decorative pieces: Art Nouveau friezes, company signs, stove tiles, and architectural elements salvaged from demolished buildings. Each panel illustrates a facet of earthenware art: advertising, architecture, technical virtuosity. Free access year-round.

activities.text: Stroll through the German district (Deutsches Viertel) built between 1870 and 1918 during the German annexation. Neo-Gothic buildings, half-timbered houses, and bourgeois villas with Art Nouveau facades line the streets. The Sainte-Croix church (1886) in red sandstone, the town hall (1895) with its 46-meter tower, and the Protestant temple (1897) illustrate Wilhelminian architecture. A unique cross-border architectural heritage.

Cross the Saar footbridge to Germany and walk along the riverbanks connecting France and Saarland. The promenade links Sarreguemines to Saarbrücken through 15 km of greenways. Medieval mills, locks, and old factories punctuate the route. Cycling possible, bike rentals available on the French side. A border walk illustrating the Franco-German reconciliation.

visits.text: The Sisteron citadel crowns the rocky spur blocking the Durance valley. The imposing fortress displays its bastioned enclosures and keep over eight centuries of military architecture. The underground staircase of 258 steps carved into rock in the 19th century links the town to the citadel in a mysterious ascent.

Notre-Dame-des-Pommiers cathedral blends Provençal Romanesque and Lombard influences. The sober 12th-century building displays a harmoniously proportioned nave. Side chapels house Baroque works and the 19th-century great organ resounds during summer concerts.

Walk through old town streets tiered between Durance and citadel. 14th-century medieval towers punctuate the former ramparts' layout. Renaissance fountains and fortified gates mark this labyrinth where Provençal town atmosphere reigns.

The Baume rock rises facing the citadel on the other side of the Durance. Horizontal limestone strata give the impression of a stack of slices. This remarkable geological site dominates the cluse where the valley narrows.

Medieval watchtowers punctuate the old town's perimeter. Five of them were preserved thanks to Prosper Mérimée. Round outward and open toward the town, they testify to Sisteron's medieval defensive system.

activities.text: The Sisteron via ferrata winds on the Baume rock walls. Cables, ladders and aerial footbridges allow a vertiginous ascent. The equipped route offers thrills safely with plunging views over the Durance and citadel.

Paragliding takes off from surrounding heights. The Durance valley's powerful thermals carry wings in an aerial ballet. The panorama embraces citadel, Durance and Alpine valleys in an unforgettable flight.

The Route Napoléon crosses Sisteron on the Emperor's return historic route. On March 5, 1815, Napoleon crossed the town without resistance during his march to Grenoble. A museum in the citadel traces this epic episode of French history.

Hiking trails radiate around Sisteron. The Baume rock ascent offers a sporty route rewarded by an exceptional panorama. The nearby Méouge gorges offer swimming and water hiking in a preserved setting.

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-De-Haute-Provence Circuit: Lavender and Perched Villages

visits.text: Saint-Jean-des-Vignes Abbey displays its Gothic facade with two 75-meter spires. Founded in 1076, this Augustinian monastery experienced brilliant medieval prosperity before Revolutionary sale. The ruins preserve remarkable Gothic architecture with refectory, cloister and chapter house. A museum presents abbey life and heritage conservation.

The Saint-Gervais and Saint-Protais Cathedral mixes Romanesque and Gothic styles over four centuries of construction. The south transept displays pure Gothic while other parts retain Romanesque elements. The Merovingian crypt, among France's oldest, shelters sarcophagi and archaeological vestiges.

Explore the 12th-century underground Saint-Léger crypt beneath the old abbey. This Romanesque space preserves remarkable carved capitals. Vaulted galleries create a mysterious atmosphere charged with history.
Stroll along the Aisne River banks and canal. Promenades follow the water through greenery. Locks and boats enliven this fluvial landscape offering peaceful views.

activities.text: Visit the arsenal museum presenting French military heritage. Collections include weapons, uniforms and equipment from medieval times to present. Interactive displays explain French army evolution.
Walk the Clovis Path retracing Frankish king's history who was baptized in Reims but spent time in Soissons. Interpretation panels dot this heritage circuit through the historic city.
Cycle the Aisne greenway converted from an old railway. The flat route suitable for all levels winds through countryside and villages. Several loops allow half-day or full-day rides.

visits.text: The Old Bridge has spanned the Bévéra since the 13th century: symbol of Sospel, it served as a toll on the Salt Route to Italy.

Fort Saint-Roch opens its depths: 2,000 meters of underground galleries, remnant of the Alpine Maginot Line carved from 5,000 m³ of concrete.
Complete your exploration at Fort de l'Agaisen, another fortified structure bearing witness to World War II defenses.
The trompe-l'oeil facades of the old town display ochre and pink hues, legacy of neighboring Liguria.

activities.text: Lace up your boots for the Bévéra Valley: the trail climbs toward the mythical Col de Turini, the Mediterranean and the Alps share the horizon.
Hop on an electric mountain bike on Mercantour circuits: gentle routes for beginners or single tracks for experts.
The Piaon gorges await canyoning enthusiasts: rappel descents, natural slides, wild landscapes.
On Thursday mornings, Place des Platanes comes alive: goat cheeses, mountain honey, olive oil from the hills.
Challenge the Route des Grandes Alpes by bike: legendary passes succeed one another beneath the pines, with Turini as the crowning glory.

visits.text: The Souvigny priory, dependency of Cluny Abbey, ranks among the five most important Cluniac sites with Cluny, Paray-le-Monial, Vézelay and La Charité-sur-Loire. The priory church Saint-Pierre-et-Saint-Paul (11th-15th centuries) combines Romanesque and Gothic. Its two bell towers, one Romanesque and the other Gothic, symbolize architectural evolution over four centuries of construction.

The Bourbon Necropolis shelters tombs of Louis II de Bourbon (†1410) and wife Anne Dauphine d'Auvergne, and of Charles I de Bourbon (†1456) and wife Agnès de Bourgogne. These sculpted black marble gisants testify to ducal power and artistic refinement of the 15th century. The tombs constitute exceptional funeral art treasures classified as Historic Monuments.

The Zodiac Column (12th century), unique in France, rises 5.30m displaying sculpted capitals representing signs of the zodiac, months of the year and agricultural labors. This Romanesque masterpiece illustrates medieval cosmic vision linking celestial time and earthly rhythms. A rare and precious testimony of Romanesque symbolic art.

The Saint-Marc Museum occupies former prior's building (17th century) presenting Souvigny priory history and treasures. Excavated capitals, liturgical objects and historical documents trace spiritual and artistic life of this major Cluniac center. Temporary exhibitions highlight medieval heritage and sacred art.

activities.text: Walk the historic village discovering stone houses (17th-18th centuries) and Saint-Marc church (11th-12th centuries). Narrow streets reveal ancient facades and small squares where priory past resonates. The village preserves an authentic monastic atmosphere.

The Tronçais Forest, one of the most beautiful oak forests in Europe, extends over 10,600 hectares just 20 km from Souvigny. Marked trails wind through three-century-old trees including oaks exceeding 40 meters. Ponds, glades and forest roads invite hiking and nature discovery.

Talloires-Montmin nestles in Lake Annecy's most beautiful bay. Cézanne, Napoleon III, and Churchill succumbed to the charm of this village nicknamed the Pearl of the Lake.
The former 11th-century Benedictine priory now houses an American university campus. Its terraced gardens descend to turquoise waters.
The 17th-century Abbey was built by Benedictine monks on the site of a 9th-century monastery. It overlooks the marina.
The Roc de Chère nature reserve preserves 68 hectares of forests and cliffs. Trails lead to viewpoints offering plunging views over the lake.
Saint-Germain's Hermitage and its cave nestle in the cliff. This pilgrimage site offers an exceptional panorama of Talloires and the lake.
The Angon Waterfall plunges 60 meters down a cliff in a green setting. The path follows the rock face to the base of this impressive cascade.

activities.text: Hiking to the Col de la Forclaz.
Canyoning in Angon Canyon is the region's signature activity. Rappels under waterfalls, natural slides, and jumps spice up this aquatic descent.
Take off paragliding from the Forclaz Pass to soar over the lake and mountains. Tandem flights offer unforgettable sensations facing the Alpine panorama.
The Roc de Chère hike winds through a forest with varied atmospheres: Mediterranean pine groves and mountain beech forests coexist on this promontory.
Rent a kayak or paddleboard to explore Talloires Bay from the water and discover coves inaccessible by road.

visits.text: The Museum of Wonders unveils 5,000 years of history: archaeological collections, Bronze Age rock engravings, alpine ethnology in a modern setting.
Lose yourself in the medieval village of Tende: houses tier like an amphitheater on the hill, cobbled lanes wind between lauze roofs and stone facades.
The Collegiate Church of Notre-Dame-de-l'Assomption raises its Romanesque bell tower and Baroque decor at the heart of the town, testament to past riches on the Salt Route.
Climb to the ruins of Lascaris Castle and the Clock Tower: the panorama embraces the Roya Valley and Mercantour peaks.
The Vallo Alpino Museum traces the military stakes of this border region during World War II.
Discover the Honey House: bees and their products are part of the agricultural heritage of these alpine valleys.
Journey aboard the Train des Merveilles connecting Nice to Tende.
Visit to the Musée des Merveilles dedicated to prehistoric rock engravings.

activities.text: The Valley of Wonders awaits hikers: over 50,000 rock engravings scattered across the slopes of Mont Bégo, an open-air museum unique in Europe.
Mountain bike the High Salt Route: the ancient mule track winds at 2,000 meters altitude between forts, chapels, and customs posts.
Board the Train des Merveilles from Tende station: vertiginous tunnels, suspended viaducts, one of France's most beautiful railway lines.
Hike in Fontanalba Valley: engravings describe the pastoral life of Neolithic shepherds, chamois and marmots populate the alpine meadows.
Head to the hamlet of Castérino, gateway to archaeological sites and starting point for alpine hikes.
Guided hike in the Vallée des Merveilles to observe rock engravings.

visits.text: The Tour aux Puces, a massive 14th-century donjon 30 meters high, dominated the Moselle valley with its 4-meter-thick walls. This remnant of the medieval fortifications houses the Thionville municipal museum, with Gallo-Roman collections and exhibits on 1,000 years of border history. From the top, the panorama extends from Luxembourg to Germany. The tower owes its name to a flea market that was held at its feet.

Vauban's casemates, designed between 1679 and 1687, plunge into 500 meters of underground galleries dug into the rock. These defensive tunnels could accommodate 1,200 soldiers and controlled access to the Luxembourg border. The vaulted chambers, powder magazines, and countermine wells tell the story of 17th-century military engineering. The temperature stays constant at 12°C year-round.

activities.text: Walk along the Moselle riverbanks, redesigned between 2010 and 2015 into green promenades. The riverside path connects the medieval Cloister Park with contemporary gardens, passing by the 18th-century Château de Guentrange and its French garden. Plane trees, rose gardens, and playgrounds line the 3 km of walkways. In summer, outdoor cafes and river shuttle boats enliven the quays.

Explore the historic center where the Saint-Maximin church (12th-16th centuries) displays a flamboyant Gothic facade topped by a 54-meter bell tower. The pedestrian streets of the old town preserve 18th and 19th-century bourgeois houses with colored facades. The Place du Marché, bordered by 18th-century arcades, hosts a market on Wednesday and Saturday mornings, perpetuating a 700-year tradition.

visits.text: Trévoux, former capital of the Principality of Dombes, raises its medieval towers above the Saône. The City of Art and History label crowns this exceptional heritage.
The Castle has dominated the town since the 14th century. Its octagonal tower offers a splendid panorama over the Saône valley and the Beaujolais hills.
The Parliament of Dombes sat here until the Revolution. The restored rooms evoke the independence of this principality that even minted its own currency.
The Carré Patrimoines houses the apothecary of the former hospital, a remarkable collection of faiences and ointment jars in their period woodwork setting.
Cross the footbridge spanning the Saône to contemplate the only town in the Saône Valley with a full southern exposure. The mirror effect on the water creates a striking tableau.
Steep alleyways lead to artist and artisan workshops. The Rue des Arts emblem marks galleries and studios where sculptors and painters open their doors.

Trévoux, former capital of the Principality of Dombes, unfolds its medieval heritage along the right bank of the Saône. The town knew its golden age under the Princes of Dombes who maintained an independent court and their own parliament from the 15th to 18th centuries. The castle perched on the rock, rampart vestiges, and narrow streets climbing the hillside testify to this prestigious past.

The Château de Trévoux, partially restored, dominates the city from its rocky outcrop. The fortified enclosure, round towers, and keep evoke medieval architecture. The site houses a museum retracing the history of the Principality of Dombes through objects, documents, and reconstructions. The terrace offers panoramic views of the Saône, surrounding plains, and distant Alps.

The former Parliament of Dombes, built in the 17th century, served as the seat of sovereignty for this autonomous principality. The building, with its classical facade and period interior layout, hosts exhibitions on Dombes' judicial and political history. The wood-paneled council chambers and ancient courtrooms transport visitors into the 18th century. Guided tours reveal surprising anecdotes about this unique institution in France.

The Church of Saint-Symphorien, rebuilt in the 19th century in neo-Gothic style, houses an exceptional collection of religious furniture from demolished Dombes churches. Carved altarpieces, period statues, and golden reliquaries form a remarkable ensemble. The recently restored stained glass windows depict scenes from local religious history.

activities.text: Pick up the discovery trail at the tourist office. Each station on the circuit reveals a piece of the history of this Lyonnaise Monaco.
The Voie Bleue follows the Saône for 700 km from Luxembourg to Lyon. Hop on a bike to ride the section through the town.
The family activity booklet transforms the visit into a treasure hunt for children ages 6 and up.

Walk the Heritage Trail that winds through old town. The marked route passes by Renaissance houses, ancient mansions, and medieval vestiges. Information panels reveal the history of the Principality of Dombes and daily life of its inhabitants. The climb to the castle offers breathtaking views of surrounding landscapes at each turn.

Cruise the Saône aboard a traditional gabarre, these flat-bottomed boats that once transported goods. The cruise offers a different perspective on the city and river landscapes. Skippers, passionate about local history, recount river anecdotes and evolution of river transport. The calm waters and preserved nature create a relaxing atmosphere.

Visit the Museum of Old Trévoux, housed in a beautiful 18th-century mansion. The collections illustrate daily life in the principality: period furniture, work tools, traditional costumes. A room dedicated to the famous Trévoux dictionary, published in the 18th century, explains the importance of this monumental work in French language history.

Explore the covered market and local shops offering Dombes specialties: pond fish, frog legs, duck foie gras. Producers explain the particularities of this marshy land dotted with a thousand ponds. The Friday morning market overflows with fresh products and creates a friendly atmosphere. Tastings allow discovery of this unique gastronomy.

visits.text: Vaux-en-Beaujolais, the real Clochemerle made famous by Gabriel Chevallier's satirical novel, has kept the soul of a Beaujolais wine village where life flows peacefully. The novel, published in 1934, depicted the colorful rivalries and picturesque characters of a wine village. The town embraced this literary identity by creating a circuit retracing locations described in the book. Golden stone houses and flower-filled alleys preserve authentic charm untouched by time.

The famous public urinal, at the heart of literary controversy, stands on the church square as a symbol of local humor. The monument, erected as homage to the novel, became a pilgrimage destination for literature lovers. A nearby panel recounts the story of this scandalous facility that divided the fictional village. The Church of Saint-Pierre overlooks this unusual square with its Romanesque bell tower.

The Musée Clochemerle, housed in the old town hall, immerses visitors in the universe of Gabriel Chevallier's novel. Period objects, photographs, and excerpts recreate the atmosphere of the 1930s and the story's colorful characters. The collection includes original editions, translations into dozens of languages, and film adaptations. A wine tasting room completes the visit with local Beaujolais.

Walk the Heritage Trail that winds through vineyards and hamlets. Information panels reveal the history of golden stone houses, vaulted wine cellars, and bread ovens. The circuit passes by the wash house where village women gathered, crosses vineyards stretching to the horizon, and climbs to belvederes offering views of surrounding valleys.

activities.text: Taste Beaujolais wines at family estates that have cultivated vines for generations. Independent winegrowers open their cellars to explain their work and passion. Tastings include different cuvées to understand terroir diversity. The warm welcome and informality typical of Beaujolais make each visit a moment of authentic sharing. Some estates offer picnics in the vineyards with a view.

Attend a reading of excerpts from Clochemerle at the village café, organized regularly by a local theater troupe. Actors bring the novel's colorful characters to life with humor and authentic local accent. The informal atmosphere encourages exchanges between spectators who share their memories of reading the book. A Beaujolais tasting follows the performance.

Cycle through surrounding vineyards on small roads where cars rarely pass. The gentle terrain makes cycling accessible to everyone. The route connects several wine hamlets, passes through century-old vines, and offers spectacular views of Mont Blanc on clear days. Stops at independent winegrowers allow discovery of production diversity.

Visit during the Fête Raclet in October, celebrating Beaujolais gastronomy. Village producers offer tastings of new wines, local charcuterie, and regional cheeses. Street entertainment, concerts, and wine-related games create a festive and friendly atmosphere. The tradition of mâchon beaujolais, this hearty breakfast accompanying morning tastings, delights the curious.

visits.text: The fortified churches of Thiérache form a unique heritage ensemble. Sixty buildings were fortified in the 16th and 17th centuries by the villagers themselves to resist constant raids. Watchtowers, loopholes and refuge rooms testify to exceptional religious military architecture. Burelles, Prisces with its 25-meter keep, and Parfondeval offer the most remarkable examples.
Vervins preserves remains of its old fortifications. The upper town reveals its strategic past as a border city with traces of ramparts still visible in some streets.
The Thiérache bocage rolls between meadows and hedges. Red brick villages dot this preserved rural landscape where fortified churches dominate the green horizons.
Follow the signposted tourist route of fortified churches on the Pays de Thiérache map. This orange circuit crosses the valleys of Brune and Serre linking the most spectacular buildings.

activities.text: The Thiérache region cultivates dairy farming traditions. Maroilles cheese, emblematic of the terroir, is produced in local farms. Some dairies offer visits and tastings of this strong-smelling cheese with distinctive flavor.
Walk the marked trails connecting fortified churches through the bocage. Several loops allow half-day or full-day hikes through this preserved rural heritage.
Visit craft workshops perpetuating traditional know-how. Local artisans work wood, forge iron and create pottery according to ancestral methods.

visits.text: The Georges de La Tour museum, inaugurated in 2003 in a contemporary building, pays tribute to the master of chiaroscuro born in Vic in 1593. The permanent exhibition presents a collection of 17th-century paintings, contextualizing La Tour's work within the Baroque movement. Temporary exhibitions explore influences and contemporaries. Didactic multimedia spaces explain the painter's revolutionary technique: controlled light, mystical atmospheres, and humble models treated with nobility.

The Saint-Marien collegiate church from the 13th-15th centuries preserves Renaissance stained glass windows from the 16th century and remarkable liturgical furniture: 18th-century stalls, 1749 Wegmann organ, and baroque paintings. Its squat 50-meter bell tower dominates the mechanical tile roofs of the village, a sandstone sentinel watching over the former salt marshes that made Vic's fortune from the 11th to 17th century with 27 salt works producing 60,000 tons of salt per year.

activities.text: Discover the history of salt in the Saulnois region, land of 400 salt springs exploited since Gallic then Gallo-Roman times. The salt marshes of Vic, Moyenvic, and Marsal produced 'white gold' in the Middle Ages by solar evaporation in lead pans. A little-known heritage that shaped the Lorraine economy until the 18th century, controlled by the bishops of Metz who drew immense revenues from it. The flat country of shimmering ponds as far as the eye can see preserves this unique landscape.

Stroll through the streets of Vic-sur-Seille, a characterful village of 1,200 inhabitants with houses of pink Vosges sandstone. Ancient salt works including Gallic briquetages, 16th-17th-century Renaissance mansions, sandstone fountains, and wash houses tell the story of the prosperity of a city that exported its 'white gold' by river to Nancy, Metz, and even Burgundy. Partially preserved medieval ramparts.

days_plan.itin_title: Moselle Circuit 10 Days: Metz, Bitche Citadel and Chagall Stained Glass

visits.text: The Hall des Sources (1903) displays its Art Nouveau metal structure, a true vessel of glass and steel designed by Charles Le Cœur. Its ironwork signed by Émile Robert reproduces the park's thistles, while five thermal springs gush forth: Célestins, Lucas, Hôpital, Chomel and Grande Grille. Mineral water can be tasted free of charge at the bars installed in this luminous hall.

The Vichy Opera (inaugurated in 1903) houses an Art Nouveau hall with 1486 seats decorated by Léon Rudnicki. Inside the dome, the faces of famous artists like Sarah Bernhardt adorn the ceiling. This Congress Palace-Opera, classified as UNESCO World Heritage, combines today historic and contemporary spaces in a unique setting in France.

The Thermes des Dômes, recognizable by their neo-Moorish dome, rank Vichy among major thermal resorts. Built between 1899 and 1903, these first-class thermal baths offer 46 treatment cabins in a preserved Belle Époque decor. The waters rich in sodium bicarbonate have treated digestive ailments and rheumatism for 2000 years.

The Parc des Sources extends around the eponymous Hall, created in 1812 by decree of Napoleon I. Its wrought-iron covered galleries (1899-1903) connect the park to the Congress Palace-Opera. The 700-meter-long promenades allow strolling in this green lung where thermal architecture dialogues with nature.

The Napoleon III Park (1861) extends its 7.8 hectares of English gardens along a 2.5 km dike protecting from Allier floods. Rare and exotic species (cedars, sequoias, Judas trees) populate this romantic haven. The imperial chalets in colonial style, built between 1863 and 1864, testify to Napoleon III's stays who made Vichy the queen of spa towns.

activities.text: The Grand Café Casino, nestled in the Parc des Sources near the Opera, invites you to try your luck at poker, roulette or one of the 100 slot machines. This Belle Époque establishment perpetuates the playful tradition of the thermal resort, attracting spa guests and visitors in a festive and friendly atmosphere.

The thermal quarter reveals its Art Nouveau facades and covered passages with film-like allure. Rue Alquié aligns its English-style houses, Rue de Belgique exhibits its baroque facades, while the Napoleon III chalets of colonial inspiration recall the splendor of the Second Empire. Vichy architecture offers an assumed bourgeois side, legacy of the thermal golden age.

The Allier riverbanks invite strolling along the artificial lake created in 1963. Plage des Célestins, guinguettes and green spaces offer relaxation and leisure by the water. The promenade continues on 4 km of developed cycle paths, perfect for enjoying the golden hour by the river.

visits.text: The Bird Park of Villars-les-Dombes brings together over 3,000 birds of 300 different species in a green setting of 35 hectares. Immersive aviaries allow close encounters with the rarest species.
Walk the interpretation trail at Chapelier Pond where two ornithological observatories offer prime viewpoints for watching the wild birdlife of the Dombes.
Notre-Dame des Dombes Abbey stands with its Cistercian buildings amid the ponds. The monks' footpath invites a meditative stroll through this landscape of water and sky.
Discover the educational farm where farmyard animals mingle with cows and horses. Children participate in daily care and bread-making workshops.
The land of a thousand ponds spreads its water mirrors as far as the eye can see. These artificial bodies of water dug by monks in the Middle Ages shape a landscape unique in France.

activities.text: Rent bikes and ride the Fairy of a Thousand Ponds circuit, winding between bodies of water where clouds are reflected.
Take off in a hot air balloon to contemplate from the sky this aquatic checkerboard dotted with farms with red-tiled roofs.
Try canicross hiking with sled dogs who guide you along the paths bordering the ponds.
Horse-drawn carriages offer guided tours through the Dombes, set to the tranquil pace of Percheron horses.

visits.text: Bell foundry.
Copper workshops.
Templar commandery.
Villedieu-les-Poêles — copper workshops & bell foundry.

Explore Villedieu-les-Poêles, a remarkable town bearing the prestigious 'Villes et Métiers d'Art' label for its extraordinary artisan heritage dating back to the Middle Ages. This living museum of traditional craftsmanship has been renowned for centuries for its exceptional copperwork, with workshops still producing magnificent handcrafted pieces using ancestral techniques passed down through generations.

Visit the Cornille Havard bell foundry, one of France's last remaining traditional bell foundries where master craftsmen continue the ancient art of bell casting. Witness the fascinating process of creating these resonant instruments using methods virtually unchanged since medieval times, and learn how these workshops have supplied bells to churches and cathedrals throughout France and beyond.

activities.text: Discover the renowned Saint James workshops, home to the iconic French knitwear brand celebrated for its authentic marinière stripes and premium wool sweaters. Tour the production facilities to witness skilled artisans creating these timeless garments, then browse the boutique for beautifully crafted pieces embodying Norman maritime heritage.

visits.text: Cross the drawbridge of the Saint-Elme Citadel: this 1557 fortress commissioned by the Duke of Savoy now houses shaded gardens and small museums.
The walls of Saint Peter's Chapel tell the story of the fishermen's patron saint: vibrant frescoes, complete decor painted in the 1950s by a famous Menton artist.
The old town clings to the hillside: cobbled lanes, colorful shutters, vertiginous staircases typical of the County of Nice.
Walk through Rue Obscure, a 130-meter vaulted passage plunged in shadow: this ancient 13th-century walkway served as shelter during bombings.
Saint Michael's Church displays its Baroque splendor beneath 18th-century vaults, with a historic organ enthroned in the gallery.
Continue to the Royal Port of La Darse, former military harbor of the Kings of Sardinia where the rope factory and shipbuilding basin remain.
Villefranche-sur-Mer — old pastel town and sloping streets down to the waterfront.

activities.text: Lay your towel on Marinières beach: fine sand, calm waveless waters, panoramic view of the harbor and the Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat peninsula.
The colorful facades of Quai de l'Amiral Courbet blaze under the sun. Settle on a terrace facing the Mediterranean.
Walk along the ramparts via the Chemin de Ronde: walls plunge into the sea, the sun sets on the horizon.
Dive into the Villefranche harbor, one of the deepest in the Mediterranean: the seabed attracts divers and freedivers from around the world.
Drive up to the corniches for postcard panoramas: the Basse Corniche offers the classic view, the Moyenne Corniche dominates from above.
Marinières Beach — swimming/snorkeling in the harbor (clear waters).
Walk from quai de la Santé to port de la Darse (photo spots).

days_plan.itin_title: Alpes-Maritimes: The Ultimate French Riviera to Alpine Peaks Adventure
French Riviera Hidden Gems: Coastal Towns & Perched Village Itinerary

visits.text: Villefranche-sur-Saône, economic capital of Beaujolais, charms with its Rue Nationale lined with Renaissance facades and inner courtyards. Founded in the 12th century by the Lords of Beaujeu, the town prospered through trade and viticulture. The arcaded houses, sculpted corbels, and hidden courtyards testify to past wealth. The 500-meter-long main street concentrates architectural treasures accumulated over centuries.

Notre-Dame des Marais Collegiate Church stands out with its impressive facade and 55-meter-high bell tower dominating the city. Built from the 13th to 15th centuries, it showcases the evolution of Gothic style. The ribbed vaults, stained glass windows, and carved capitals create a majestic interior space. The recently restored organ ranks among the finest in the region.

The Municipal Museum Paul Dini houses an exceptional collection of modern and contemporary art. Works by Renoir, Dufy, Picasso, and local artists illustrate artistic movements of the 20th century. Temporary exhibitions showcase emerging artists and current trends. The building itself, a beautifully restored 18th-century mansion, is worth the visit.

The Covered Market, built in the 19th century, buzzes with activity every morning except Monday. The metal and glass structure shelters stalls overflowing with local products: Beaujolais wines, regional charcuterie, mountain cheeses, seasonal vegetables. Exchanges between producers and customers perpetuate the tradition of direct sales. The festive atmosphere and authentic smells create a total immersion in Beaujolais gastronomy.

activities.text: Explore the inner courtyards hidden behind Renaissance facades of Rue Nationale. These secret spaces, once economic heart of the city, reveal spiral staircases, sculpted galleries, and ancient wells. Some courtyards have been magnificently restored and now house artisan shops and artist studios. Guided tours reveal the history of merchant families who built their fortunes here.

Stroll along the Saône on the newly developed waterfront. The shaded promenade offers views of the river and surrounding hills. Play areas, picnic areas, and flowered gardens invite rest. Swans and ducks enliven the peaceful waters. The path connects to walking trails extending along the riverbanks.

Visit during the Beaujolais Nouveau festival in November, when the city becomes the epicenter of worldwide celebrations. Producers set up stands offering tastings of the new vintage. Concerts, wine-related games, and fireworks animate the streets. The festive atmosphere attracts thousands of visitors who share a glass around street braziers.

Take a walking tour of street art that has transformed many facades in recent years. Local and international artists created murals depicting Beaujolais history, wine culture, and urban life. The works, scattered throughout the city, offer a contemporary artistic journey contrasting with Renaissance heritage. Maps available at the tourist office guide visitors through this open-air gallery.

Yvoire spreads its ramparts and flower-lined lanes on a promontory jutting into Lake Geneva. This 14th-century fortified village ranks among France's Most Beautiful Villages.
The castle has dominated the lake since 1306 when Count Amédée V of Savoy fortified this strategic point. Private property, it can be admired from the fishing port.
Pass through the Nernier Gate topped by its watchtower to enter the medieval town. Cobbled lanes wind between stone houses with flower-bedecked balconies.
Saint-Pancrace Church raises its onion dome covered in stainless steel that shines like a beacon on the lake. Pastel-colored interior frescoes illuminate the nave.
The Garden of Five Senses occupies the castle's former vegetable garden. This plant labyrinth gathers 1,300 varieties chosen to stimulate each of the senses.
The marina welcomes boats from Switzerland while the small fishing port retains its authenticity with colorful skiffs.
The Faucille Pass peaks at 1,323 meters on the Jura ridge. The panorama embraces Lake Geneva, Mont Blanc, and the entire Alpine chain.
Chamonix: stroll in the historic center at the foot of Mont-Blanc.
Chamonix Alpine Museum: collections on mountaineering and first ascents.
Yvoire: medieval town on the shores of Lake Geneva, discovery of the fortified alleys.
Garden of the Five Senses in Yvoire: sensory trail organized by themes.

activities.text: The ferry links Yvoire to Nyon in Switzerland in twenty minutes. This crossing offers a unique viewpoint of the fortified village with the Alps as backdrop.
Stroll through pedestrian lanes lined with artisan shops and art galleries. Restaurants serve lake fish on shaded terraces.
The Garden of Five Senses offers a unique sensory experience where textures, fragrances, flavors, sounds, and colors mingle in a plant setting.
The Faucille Pass toboggan run descends over a kilometer with slopes reaching 37 percent. This descent ranks among Europe's longest.
Aiguille du Midi cable car: panoramic ascent over the Mont-Blanc massif.
Panoramic transfer Chamonix → Yvoire along Lake Geneva (viewpoint stops).

visits.text: Plaine des Cafres — Volcano Museum (Cité du Volcan) introducing Piton de la Fournaise.
Plaine des Sables — Lunar ash plains on the access road to the volcano.

activities.text: Star‑gazing session (clear nights) on the high plateau; bring warm layers.

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: RN5 to Cilaos — Road of 400 bends, basalt cliffs and tunnels; scenic stops at Îlet à Cordes viewpoint.
Cilaos — Thermal heritage, embroidery workshop and Cirque panoramas.
Cirque de Cilaos — Day hike on the Bras Rouge sector; basalt pools and cascades.
Village craft center — Lace and lentil products from the plateau.

activities.text: Short hike to La Roche Merveilleuse belvedere (late afternoon light).
Spa soak or wine tasting (local chenin/viognier micro‑production).
Optional summit attempt to Piton des Neiges (very early start; experienced hikers).

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: Salazie — Voile de la Mariée waterfalls and fern canyons; viewpoints along RD48.
Hell‑Bourg — Restored Creole villas (Maison Folio) and village museum.

activities.text: Easy loop hike around Hell‑Bourg (2–3 h, early start to avoid clouds).
Cassava cake and bonbon piment tasting in a village snack.

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: Saint‑Denis — Barachois waterfront cannons and Creole townhouses on Rue de Paris (19th c.).
Jardin de l’État — Botanical collections and natural‑history museum in a colonial garden.
Back to Saint‑Denis — Street art lanes and last Creole boutiques.

activities.text: Evening cari and rhum arrangé tasting; book a table on Rue Maréchal Leclerc.
Short seaside jog on the Barachois promenade at sunrise.
Final seaside walk at Barachois; airport drop‑off.

visits.text: Saint‑Paul market (Fri–Sat) — Spices, fruits and Creole street food.
Saint‑Gilles‑les‑Bains — Aquarium and marina promenade.
Maïdo road — Belvedere over the Mafate cirque; panoramas at 2190 m (arrive at sunrise).
Savanna distillery — Rum tasting and botanical garden (check hours).

activities.text: Lagoon snorkeling at l’Ermitage (inside reef only; heed lifeguard flags).
Paragliding over the lagoon (weather‑dependent; certified operator only).

days_plan.itin_title: Réunion Island Tour: Piton de la Fournaise Volcano and Cirques

visits.text: Étang‑Salé — Black‑sand beach and petrified lava cliffs.
Saint‑Pierre — Waterfront market and Creole temple façades on Rue des Bons‑Enfants.

activities.text: Snorkel the protected lagoon (when sea is calm; never swim outside marked area).

visits.text: Piton de la Fournaise — Hike from Pas de Bellecombe to the caldera rim with views of Dolomieu crater.
Grand Brûlé — Coastal lava flows and N2 road segments rebuilt over recent eruptions.

activities.text: Stop at Notre‑Dame des Laves chapel near Piton‑Sainte‑Rose.
